Form No. 101
Sir,

I have been requested by the teacher and the council of the Alnwick Band to ask the department for a grant of $12.00, to help defray the expense of a day's outing for the school children. The money received would be used to supply trucks for transportation of the children.

It was suggested by some, to take the children to Cobourg, Ont. on May 6th. to take part in the big Jubilee Parade to be held there, I was not in favour of doing so, and promised them I would do what I could to get them a day off later on, if they would refrain from going in there on that day, and I would recommend that this request for this small grant be allowed them.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 10th, 1956.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 4th instant asking that a grant of $12.00 be made to defray the expenses of a day's outing for the school children.

If the Council passes a resolution recommending the expenditure of $10.00 from Band Funds for this purpose, the same will be approved.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. O. Grieve, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Roseneath, Ont.
COPY OF RESOLUTION.

Moved by Stanley Hagar, and seconded by Norman Marsden, that this council ask the Department, for a grant of $10.00, from band funds, to assist in giving the school children, a day's outing, (carried)
Sir;—

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant, wherein you state, that if the council passed a resolution, recommending the expenditure of $10.00, from band funds for the purpose of giving the school children a day's outing, the same would be approved,

I may say in this connection, that this has been done, and am enclosing a copy of the resolution,

Your Obedient Servant

Form No. 101
Roseneath Sept 5th, 1935,

Sir;— At yesterday's meeting of the Alnwick Indian Council, a resolution was passed, asking that a new pump be purchased for the well at the school on the reserve, and the well cleaned out.

In this connection I may say that a new pump is needed for the well, as the old one is worn out, and they have to carry water some distance for the school. The well is about forty feet deep, and the cost for the pump, and cleaning the well, would be around Thirty or thirty five Dollars, and I would suggest, that a new pump be installed, and the well cleaned out.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Indian Agent

Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa,
Ottawa, September 10, 1935.

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Form No. 101
Roseneath September 5th, 1936,

Sir;-

I beg to report, that at the opening of the Alnwick Agency Day School, there was not seating accommodation for the children, so I secured a carpenter, and had temporary seats built, to take care of the situation for the present.

It may be that this large attendance will not last for very long, as the novelty of the new teacher will wear away, and there are some families who leave the reserve for the winter; however; if this attendance continues we will have to secure some new seats.

Your Obedient Servant

Indian Agent

Secretary
Dep't Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,-

I enclose a Resolution of the Alnwick Band Council passed at a meeting held on July 25th wherein they request that a sum of $100.00 be authorized from band funds for the purpose of redecorating the school room in the Alnwick Band Council Hall.

This school room has windows on the east and west and has no light from the south or north. It is quite dark on account of this lighting arrangement and the dark paint with which it was decorated some number of years ago. There is some staining from the roof leaking prior to repairs which were made last summer. During the winter months the class room is quite dark during the afternoon session and I suggest that if the room could be painted in a light cream and the dark trim be eliminated, it would make the class room more cheerful and brighter.

I would be pleased to recommend this expenditure.

"The furnace needs much repairing. The new decorations are lovely but are being destroyed by smoke."

Dear Sir,

On receipt of your letter 3-1-5 of Dec. 27th, I requested Mr. McMillan of Rosenseth, who is apparently the only heating contractor in the village, to inspect the furnace at the Alnwick Indian Day School. He reports the flues are practically burnt out as well as part of the fire pot. Apparently a piece has dropped out recently and allows smoke to come up in the class room. There has not been a great deal of damage as yet but if allowed to be used in this way it will smoke up the fresh paint and there is danger of a spark coming up the register. I have instructed the caretaker to close off all registers and place a piece of sheet metal over the registers when leaving the building at night. Mr. McMillan thinks this should eliminate the fire hazard temporarily.

Chief Ernest Crowe and myself examined this furnace in September and at that time it was from all outward appearances in satisfactory condition. About five or six years ago Mr. Grieve had the furnace repaired at a cost of about $60.00. A new outside casing was put on and a cement base. This makes the furnace appear a lot better than it actually is. When examining the furnace Mr. McMillan found that a piece of casting from the flue had completely dropped out and it is impossible to repair it.
The Secretary,

I have been in the building every week and the furnace was apparently operating satisfactorily up to the time when this section dropped out. This must have occurred during the time of Mr. Martin's inspection. The school teacher had not brought it to my attention but apparently was waiting until my trip to the Reserve.

I am satisfied that the furnace cannot be repaired from Mr. McMillan's and my own observation. Mr. McMillan has given me a figure on the cost of replacement of a new wood burning furnace adequate for heating this building. I enclose Circular given me by him of the Beach Foundry Company. This is a wood burning furnace of 50,000 cu.ft heating capacity, which can take a 4'x4" stack with 82,000 B.T.U. rating at register. He would include in his price all extras, such as new collars to fit the heating pipes and cold air pipes to make a satisfactory job for $165.00 covering complete installation and taking away the furnace.

I am sorry I am unable to get other quotations from Roseneath merchants as McMillan is the only one in this business. He has previously done satisfactory work. His price is standard for the type of furnace shown and on account of the furnace being immediately required I suggest that I may be instructed to have the furnace installed immediately.

On account of the urgency may I request that you wire me your instructions. Fires are kept low to eliminate fire hazard.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent
RICE AND MUD LAKES AGENCY

Mr. McMillan thinks this should eliminate the fire hazard temporarily.

Chief Ernest Crowe and myself examined this furnace in September and at that time it was from all outward appearances in satisfactory condition. About five or six years ago Mr. Grieve had the furnace repaired at a cost of about $60.00. A new outside casing was put on and a cement base. This makes the furnace appear a lot better than it actually is. When examining the furnace Mr. McMillan found that a piece of casting from the flue had completely dropped out and it is impossible to repair it.
The Secretary,

I have been in the building every week and the furnace was apparently operating satisfactorily up to the time when this section dropped out. This must have occurred during the time of Mr. Martin's inspection. The school teacher had not brought it to my attention but apparently was waiting until my trip to the Reserve.

I am satisfied that the furnace cannot be repaired from Mr. McMillan's and my own observation. Mr. McMillan has given me a figure on the cost of replacement of a new wood burning furnace adequate for heating this building. I enclose Circular given me by him of the Beach Foundry Company. This is a wood burning furnace of 50,000 cu.ft heating capacity, which can take a 4" stick with 82,000 B.T.U. rating at register. He would include in his price all extras, such as new collars to fit the heating pipes and cold air pipes to make a satisfactory job for $165.00 covering complete installation and taking away the old furnace.

I am sorry I am unable to get other quotations from Roseneath merchants as McMillan is the only one in this business. He has previously done satisfactory work. His price is standard for the type of furnace shown and on account of the furnace being immediately required I suggest that I may be instructed to have the furnace installed immediately.

On account of the fire hazard may I request that you wire me your instructions. Fires are kept low to eliminate fire hazard.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

RE: Alnwick School  
Your file 2-1-5

I have your letter of July 20th enclosing report of School Inspector Martin and wish to report as follows:

Toilets  
I have been endeavouring to have this work done since school closed. I have secured promise from John Smoke to have the work done forthwith.

Water Supply  
This work has been completed

Woodshed - This building was not well braced so that the amount of wood pushed at out of place. I am securing a tender from Mr. McMillan, Rosemire, for the work, when I can get this I will report. The building is in no danger.

Gable trough - It is almost impossible to secure a workman to do this repair job at present. Will continue the effort. Work not so important.

Basement - I placed order for repairs to furnace with Mr. McMillan last March. He hopes to secure the castings soon, in time for winter. Excessive rainfall accounts for damage. Ordinarily in reasonable condition. No water in the pit at present. Not readily drainable.

In reply to your letter 2-1-5 of 8th of January, 1946, requesting an estimate of the cost of repairing the woodshed attached to the Alnwick Indian Day School, the situation is as follows.

The cement foundation under the east wall of this shed has crumbled from under the shed sills and will require a new cement trench wall; the building raised up and straightened back where it should be; then braced. It has pulled away from the brick wall it is placed against but not attached, about five inches. Other than being considerably out of line and somewhat of an eye sore its usefulness has not been affected. Part of next year's supply of wood has now been placed in the shed, which would have to be removed to carry out this work.

I have had estimates submitted from $140.00 to $180.00 to repair the shed. I think it can be done for possibly a price between these two figures. I do not think the building would require to be torn down, and rebuilt.

As a trench cement wall is required to put a good foundation under it, it is doubtful whether this work could be carried out until the frost is out of the ground. There also might be at that time more favourable labour conditions for doing the work.

EXTRACT from letter from Indian Agent V.M. Eastwood dated 23rd January, 1946.

Reference Alnwick Indian Reserve School and Council Hall

Further to informing you by telephone yesterday of the fire on January 21st which completely destroyed the above building housing the Alnwick Indian Day School on the ground floor.

My first concern was to re-establish the school and I believe a satisfactory arrangement is now under way and should be completed in order to open the school on Monday the 28th. On my own responsibility I have taken over the Mission House immediately east of the ruins of the former school and through the co-operation of Mrs. Maria Bigwin and Mrs. Charlotte Crowe, residing in the Mission House, I moved Mrs. Crowe to her daughter's and Mrs. Bigwin took over the upstairs portion of the Mission House, leaving free a double room downstairs. By the removal of a temporary partition which will be of no great cost, a room is available, approximately 35 ft by 18 ft.

At present there are 30 pupils attending school. By improvising some desks or forms for desks, I believe that the school can carry on until supplies requested by emergency requisition are forthcoming. There are, incidentally some old desks although not ordinarily satisfactory, which can be braced to do temporarily. Further reference to the school is made in my letter covering this requisition.

Re: Alnwick Indian Day School, Temporary Premises.

The mission house on the Alnwick Indian reserve has been used as a temporary school since the fire which destroyed the Council Hall and school. A certain amount of repair was necessary to put this house in usable condition for the school. A new school was authorized to be built during 1947 but due to difficulty in securing tenders from contractors to complete the school it was deferred until 1948.

In the meanwhile a number of repairs were not carried out on the mission house to put it in condition for the winter months. The following repairs are now required:

1. Double Windows. There are a number of these in the basement but some of the glass is broken. There would be enough windows to put storm windows on the portion of the building used as a class room.

2. Doors. There is one door facing the west which should be boarded up or supplied with a storm door as it is not used regularly. I would prefer to have a storm door where it could be opened in case of fire or emergency.

3. Blackboards. There will be required two sections of Masonite to fill present needs. The manual training instructor has also requested a small blackboard in another room where they carry out manual training in this school.

4. Furnace. The furnace hot air and cold air pipes need repairing for the more efficient operation of the furnace.

The janitor, Thomas Marsden, could fit the windows and make the storm door and put up the blackboards. I would estimate the cost of materials at $10.00 and the labour in the neighbourhood of $15.00 for his work and possibly $12.00 to $14.00 for repairing the furnace. May I have authority to proceed with this work which is both necessary and urgent for the comfort of the children in the school.

Mines and Mud Lakes Agency.

Construction of One-room Day School and attached Teacherage - Alnwick Reserve.

We have now a stock of blue-prints, specifications and bills of materials for our standard one-room day school and attached teacher's residence.

The Auditor General has insisted that in future, the clauses of the Public Works Act with regard to advertising for tenders be adhered to. During the emergency war years, some variations from these regulations were permitted, but we are now required to advertise for tenders on construction of public buildings in excess of $5,000.00. Attached hereto please find a sample advertisement. It is our intention to advertise for tenders for the construction of the Alnwick Day School in the near future. Therefore, we would request you to advise us:

(a) The name of the newspapers in or near your agency in which you would recommend that we advertise;

(b) Post office and other government buildings in which we should display drawings, specifications, etc.

Naturally, your own office will be one in which we will display drawings, etc. If no tenders are received after advertising, you will be advised so that other means can be considered whereby the construction of this school can be carried out during the fiscal year 1948-49. These other means involve:

(a) ..... direct
1. Direct approach to contractors when advertising has failed to produce tenders.

2. Construction on a day labour basis.

3. The erection of a prefabricated school.

With regard to (2) above, the Department, as previously stated, now has a complete bill of materials for the construction of this standard school. Other agents have successfully had this school constructed this year by employing a foreman-carpenter and Indian helpers. The drawings and specifications are very clear and the Department buys all the necessary materials. I give you this information so that you can consider such a mode of construction if advertising fails.

We would appreciate receiving from you the information required in para 3. We should also be advised as to the availability of Hydro and water facilities and their distance from the school building.

Re: Alnwick Indian Day School.

In reply to file 25-3-5 dated February 1948, I have inquired into the approximate cost of a well dug for serving the new day school proposed to be erected on the Alnwick Indian Reserve.

In order to secure adequate water, I would suggest that a 36" inside measurement tile well would be preferred to a drilled well which is generally dug with 5" pipe.

The rates for a drilled well I will give first. The local rate has been $4.00 a foot through rock and $5.00 a foot through soil. I understand the reason for the difference is that through rock no casing is required although it takes longer to drill. I understand the advantage of a drilled well is that if a boulder is encountered, it is no obstacle, whereas in digging it often occasions the abandoning of that particular location on account of the difficulty of removing the rock or going around it. There is also a question whether an adequate water supply could be secured from a drilled well.

Judging from the depth of wells in this neighbourhood, I am of the opinion that the well would have to be dug to a depth of 60 ft. I can only estimate the labour roughly, two men should complete as the very outside, five feet in depth a day or better. As they go deeper the work is slowed up by the handling of the earth by bucket and is harder work. My estimate for labour would be $120.00.

Sixty feet in depth would take 24 cement tiles. There are two sizes: 30" inside measurement, 36" outside measurement, cost $5.40 inclusive of 8% sales tax. It would be preferred that the 36" tile be used. Cost of tile $171.60. My estimate would be $350.00 to $400.00 for labour and material with no difficulty encountered and sufficient water located at depth of 60'.
Indian Affairs Branch

In regard to digging, I am confident that I can secure two men, experienced in well digging, both Indians, immediately after the muskrat trapping season which should be, if the season opens early, somewhere around the 10th of April.

With reference to file 25-3-5(El) of March 16th 1948 I wish to report that I have been unable as yet to secure anybody to dig a well on the proposed site of the new school on the Alnwick Indian Reserve. I have purchased the tile and it is on the ground. I have made several trips to well diggers in the vicinity of Roseneath and the gentleman I counted on to do the work states he has enough to do to take him two years to complete. An Indian by the name of Frank Gray is willing to proceed with the work provided he can get somebody to assist him and he is to advise me later.

There is a well some 300 feet away from the proposed site of the school which I believe could be used for pouring cement for the new school so I suggest that there would be no lack of water to hold up construction of the school foundations.

May I please be advised as to whether tenders have been asked for the erection of this school. If a new school is not available for the fall term, I will have to request funds for extensive repairs for the temporary school house that is now in use. The building will require roofing, plastering inside, new flooring, and alterations to the heating plant. The building is not worth any expense but this work will be necessary to make it useable for another winter. Last winter in order to keep the children comfortable a succession of expedients to keep the building useable had to be resorted to.

af.

J. M. EASTWOOD
Superintendent,
Rice and Mud Lakes Agency.

Alnwick Indian Day School.

Reference your 2-1 (25) of June 2, 1948.

Upon receipt of your letter, we again reminded
the Lands and Development Services Branch of their promise to
supply the plumbing and electricity supplement to the plans for
a standard one-room Indian day school as intended for the
Alnwick Indian Day School.

Tenders have not been asked for the erection
of this school as we wished to be assured of a source of water
before any steps are taken. Therefore, if Frank Gray is willing
to proceed with this work, you are hereby authorized to engage
him to do so. The expenditure on the well should not exceed
the sum of $300.00. If it is necessary to exceed this sum, I
would ask that you immediately advise the Department, for
further instructions.

We have found that contractors are reticent to for-
ward firm tenders for the erection of these schools. Within the
last two months we have been able to engage a number of foremen-
carpenters across the country who are willing to supervise the
erection of this building, using local and Indian labour. The
usual rate for their services is $1.50 per hour. Under such a
day labour plan, the Department buys all the necessary materials
from a standard bill which we have prepared. It is usually necessary to arrange for sub-contracts for the electricity, plumbing, etc. Such a plan also provides for the employment of a certain amount of Indian labour and we have been quite satisfied with the type of school thus erected. As you know, the drawings and specifications are very clear and concise and have presented no difficulties for other carpenters who have erected this building.

Do you know of any such carpenter who would be willing to undertake the erection of this building under such terms. If so, I would ask that you advise the Department. I attach a copy of the standard bill of materials which we supply in such cases.

Encl.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Smoke has had considerable experience and has just completed a fifty foot well for another member of the Band. It is proposed to commence work on the 7th of June.

For the purpose of paying for labour may I have an advance accountable cheque for $250.00 to pay wages.

In reply to file 25-3-5 of the 8th of July 1948, I am now able to advise that ample water is available at the site of the proposed new school.

Failing to receive firm tenders for the erection of this school, I would suggest the name of S. J. F. McMillan, general contractor, as a foreman carpenter to supervise the erection of this school in accordance with the outline suggested in your letter. I have undertaken to secure from him his willingness to accept the job as foreman carpenter, if same is offered him.

You will recall that he tendered on the school last year. He is a resident of Roseneath which is adjacent to the Alnwick Indian Reserve. He has completed a number of private and public buildings under contract but is willing to work on the basis suggested. From inquiry and from personal experience I find him a thoroughly reliable person and capable of completing work of this nature. I would strongly recommend him to the Department.

Immediately upon receipt of your letter of August 4, a memorandum was forwarded to the Deputy Minister recommending the acceptance of Mr. McMillan as foreman carpenter for the erection of a one-room Indian Day School on the Alnwick Reserve at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

In anticipation of the acceptance of Mr. McMillan's tender, we have today requested the Departmental Purchasing Agent to provide you with 650 bags of Portland cement as required in the standard bill of materials for this school. I am also asking for authority for local purchase for the following items listed in the standard bill of materials:

- 100 " crushed Stone
- 4 " crushed pea stone
- 45 cubic yards Sand
- 230 ft. (lin.) 4" agricultural weeping tile.
- 20 lin. ft. 4" vitrified clay tile
- 120 " " 6" "

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Alnwick Indian Day School.

Included in our Estimates for 1948-49 is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room school and attached teacher's residence on the Alnwick Indian Reserve, in the Rice and Mud Lakes Agency, near Peterborough, Ont.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Eastwood has been able to obtain a tender from Mr. S. J. F. McMillan, general Contractor of Roseneath, Ont., for the supervision of this building at the rate of $1.50 per hour. Mr. McMillan would supervise the building of the school using Indian and other day labour. The Department would provide all materials through the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Eastwood remarks as follows concerning this builder:

"You will recall that he tendered on the school last year. He is a resident of Roseneath which is adjacent to the Alnwick Indian Reserve. He has completed a number of private and public buildings under contract but is willing to work on the basis suggested. From inquiry and from personal experience I find him a thoroughly reliable person and capable of completing work of this nature. I would strongly recommend him to the Department."

I would recommend that you approve the hiring of Mr. McMillan for the erection of this school at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

Director.

Res. Alnwick Indian Day School,

Your inquiry re Unemployment Insurance, Income Tax and Workmen's Compensation addressed to the Superintendent of Education has been passed to this office for reply.

You should secure forms T.D.1 or T.D.1A, whichever is applicable, from each of the men working on the above-noted school and deductions from wages should be made in accordance with the information shown thereon. The tax deducted should be forwarded to the local Director of Income Tax monthly, together with a statement showing the source of the deductions and the month it covers. Form T-4-1948 should be supplied at the close of the calendar year to each workman from whose wages a deduction for Income Tax is made. Indians working on a reserve are not subject to Income Tax.

Unemployment Insurance stamps may be purchased from your local Post Office. A copy of the licence is enclosed. Regulations and tables of contributions may be secured from your local office. Indians working on a reserve are not insurable unless they are already in possession of an Unemployment Insurance Book.

All employees of the Dominion Government are covered by the Government Employees' Compensation Act, 1947, which is administered by the Department of Transport. No deduction from pay is collected from Dominion Government employees on account of Workmen's Compensation.

Attention Col. B. F. Neary

Authority is sought for delivery by truck of the lumber, insulation etc. to be ordered from the Peterborough Lumber Company at Peterborough at an additional cost of $200.

The tender submitted was for delivery at Hastings, Ontario, the nearest rail-point to the site of the construction, a distance of twelve miles.

In delivering these materials the minimum requirement would be eighteen truck loads as there is 40,000 feet of lumber plus sash, asbestos insulation, window frames, doors etc. All these materials will not possibly be available when required necessitating possibly additional loads and shipments. If shipped by rail to Hastings, it will have to be transshipped to the site of the school necessitating additional handling and the additional cost of this transportation. I do not think it can be done for less than $6.00 or $7.00 a load and the trucks available at Roseneath are much smaller than the delivery trucks of the Peterborough Lumber Company. I would estimate that possibly there would be 25 loads costing approximately $150.

In every way the delivery by truck from Peterborough would be more satisfactory and with less handling of the materials.

Dear Sir:

Re-Alnwick Indian School and Teachers' Residence.

In arriving at the cost of transportation of the material covered by your list, we use the following basis for arriving at our cost for delivery to Hastings:

2 carloads at approximately $20.00 per carload equals $40.00
3 truckloads to consist principally of millwork and builders' supplies...........$54.00

Total of...............$94.00

Should this material all be hauled from Peterborough direct to the job at Alnwick, we estimate it will require a total of 17 truckloads @ $18.00 per truckload, making a total of..........................$306.00

By subtracting from this amount, the figure named above of........................................$94.00

There is a difference of........................................$212.00

and we suggested to you that we would undertake delivery at the round figure named of $200.00 rather than the $212.00 shown above.

As you are doubtless aware, in making shipments of lumber we use the milling in transit basis, which gives us the benefit of the through rate from the point of origin of the lumber direct to the destination (Hastings) which means in turn we have to pay a stop-off charge only of not more than 2c per hundred, and this in turns enables us to transport by rail on a much lower basis than were to pay the local rate from Peterborough to Hastings. You will
notice we have figured on 2 carloads and 3 truck loads of stock other than the lumber to arrive at our original delivered price.

The price of $18.00 per truck load is arrived at by using our out-of-pocket cost for the operating of our large trucks, of 25c per mile, and you will appreciate that this amount does not pay for the actual running of these large vehicles, but it is not our thought at any time to make a profit out of trucking. Hence the basis above used which we can assure you is a loss item with us at the end of the year.

It actually would be to our advantage to suggest that you permit us to make delivery by car to Hastings, but on the other hand realize it would not be nearly as convenient for you, and the material itself would be re-handled several times, which in the case of millwork and builders' supplies we believe would be to the disadvantage of your Department. For this reason we feel we have an obligation to you to suggest that the trucking basis is much more advantageous to you in the long run.

We trust the above explanation clarifies the situation as it applies to the most advantageous way for all concerned in arranging to get the material for this job delivered.

Yours very truly,

THE PETERBOROUGH LUMBER COMPANY LIMITED

Sec'y-Treas.

In reply to File No. 25-3-5 (E.I) of 1st October 1948 I inclose an explanatory letter from Mr. Overend of the Peterborough Lumber Company Limited setting out his costs of delivery by truck to the site of the new school, as opposed to costs to the nearest rail-point at Hastings, Ontario which is ten mile distant.

As he points out in his letter he is asking for the sum of $200.00 for trucking to the site of the school.

If the materials are shipped by rail to Hastings the best arrangement I can make is to hire trucks to draw the material from Hastings to the Reserve, a distance of ten miles, at the rate of $2.50 an hour for the use of the truck and driver with at least two helpers to unload cars, load and unload trucks. This would be $3.50 an hour. The trucks would not be as large as the Peterborough Lumber Company trucks which are specially equipped with rollers etc. for handling lumber.

The 17 truckloads as carried by the P.L. Company might make up about 25 loads with the size of load limit of the trucks I would be able to hire at Roseneath. In addition to this there will most likely be extra trips for materials not available which may be shipped later.

To load at the box car, travel ten miles, unload and return I estimate the time required would be an hour and a half, to two hours. Cost per trip $7.00 to $8.00 At $8.00 for 24 trips - $192.00.

The latter method would insure the material being delivered on the site with less handling and as required. Hardware, paint and materials not included in the lumber and millwork could be forwarded on the P.L. Trucks as it arrives, which they have consented to do.

Extra trips will, no doubt, be required with supplies.
in urgent need. I would recommend that the Peterborough Lumber Company offer be accepted.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 5 OCTOBER 1948.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 15th September, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT funds are provided in the 1943-49 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a one-room Indian Day School and teacher's residence on the Alnwick Indian Reserve, Rice and Mud Lake Indian Agency, Province of Ontario;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for the materials required for the building;

THAT the only tender received by the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the lumber and millwork has been from the Peterborough Lumber Company Limited, Peterborough, Ontario, by which they offer to supply the lumber and millwork required at a cost of $7,463.90 f.o.b. Hastings, Ontario, delivery commencing in seven days and completed as required;

THAT it is essential that these materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to allow the erection of the school to be completed before the Christmas term;

THAT the Purchasing Agent considers the price quoted to be fair and reasonable.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the Peterborough Lumber Company Limited to supply the materials on which they have quoted at a price of $7,463.90 f.o.b. Hastings, Ontario, which due to contingencies will involve an expenditure of approximately $8,000.00.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Almisk Indian Day School

Originally, we planned to build the standard one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence (index No. 837) on this reserve.

For some time now, the Architects have been working on an adaptation of this standard school to provide for toilets and electricity on reserves. This school was to be built on reserves where hydro facilities were available. The Almisk Reserve does have electricity and therefore we were anxious to have this new design, (No. 865) built there. The new plans arrived just as the foundations were being poured and we were able to change from plan 837 to plan 865. The main change in this plan insofar as you are concerned is that it calls for a forced hot air system instead of a gravity hot air system. I was able to inform Mr. Indian Superintendent Eastwood that he should approach the tenderers and advise them of the change involved and that their tenders should be for plan 865 and NOT for plan 837.

Please find attached tenders received here for the work involved in the plumbing and heating at this school. You will note that we do not intend to install an oil burner. I have discussed this matter with Mr. Simard and this will confirm our conversation. For your information, I have sent the new blueprints and specifications for plan No. 865, have been sent to you under separate cover.

Re: Alnwick Indian Day School - File 25-3-5(El)

Attention: Col. B. F. Neary

Authority is sought for substituting Johns-Mansville asbestos cedar grain shingles, oyster white, in place of insul brick siding. I am advised by Mr. Overend of the Peterborough Lumber Co. who were successful tenderers on the supply of this building material, that he can supply these shingles in place of the insul brick at a net saving of $65.50 to the Department.

It was my original understanding from the specifications that I received that the bill of materials called for the asbestos shingles but apparently a change has been made substituting insul brick and this was on the bill of materials sent to the suppliers tendering. In my opinion the asbestos grain shingles would make a better appearing school with a longer lasting exterior finish. There would be a saving of $65.50 and I am assured that there is no substantial increase in the labour cost. The school is on a prominent site on the Alnwick Indian Reserve and the church in the immediate vicinity is sheeted with wooden siding painted white. The appearance of the public buildings would be much improved by retaining the same colour.

The cement foundation walls of the new school will extend approximately five feet above the grade and this would minimize the possibility of damage caused by children at play.

I would strongly recommend that the cedar grain shingles be used in the completion of this school.

[Signature]

W.M. Eastwood, Superintendent,
Pine and Mud Lakes Agency.
MEMORANDUM:

COL. B. F. NEARY.

RE: Construction of new Alnwick School.

During my inspection of the Rice and Mud Lakes Agency on November 4th, I examined the work being done in the construction of the above-mentioned school. I found that the cement foundation had been completed. On the upper structure, the framework had been completed with siding, and the roof was shingled. In my opinion the materials are of the very best, and the workmanship is up to standard.

There were about 140 bags of cement available, and, as frost might develop at any time, I asked Mr. Eastwood to instruct his foreman to excavate immediately and run the cement for the septic tank. This, of course, made it necessary to purchase the fittings for the inside of the tank. Mr. Eastwood was able to secure them from the local hardware merchant. I also requested that the disposal bed be excavated and the necessary tile laid. It is imperative that all of this work be done before the ground freezes up, and this is the reason why these instructions were issued.

Regarding the outside finish of the building, I would recommend that Johns-Manville grain shingles be used rather than insul brick siding. It is my understanding that there will be little difference in the cost of these two materials. If the Johns-Manville shingles, in grey or white, were used, it would make a more attractive building than insul brick siding, for the reason that the roof is covered with red asphalt shingles,

Re: Alnwick Indian Day School - Plumbing and Heating Contracts.

Attention Col. B. F. Neary

It is my understanding that of the firms requested to submit tenders for the above contracts only two have been received namely, Fred. V. Goodfellow and W. R. Turner, both of Peterborough.

At your request I contacted the following firms:

Adamson & Dobbin,
Archibald & Richmond - both of Peterborough,
Milton McMillan - of Rosenotheath
K. S. Cooper - of Cobourg.

The first three firms stated they were not interested due to the pressure of work on hand, shortages of materials and the Peterborough firms stated that their workmen were not keen on boarding out which they would have to do as the job is thirty-five miles from Peterborough. In regard to K. S. Cooper, I have already advised that he could not undertake the work for three months at the earliest, that he would only consider it on a cost plus basis and on his own terms.

The school will be completely closed in by the end of this week and all the exterior work completed except for painting the windows and trim. The primer coat has been put on by Indian labour in order to protect new wood and prevent shrinkage in windows and window frames.

As to the interior, the basement drainage system has been installed and the cement floor poured. All insulation has been installed and walls and ceilings closed except where heating air ducts and leaders and plumbing installations will be installed.
While this work was in progress the electric conduit wire was installed back of the wells, with outlets.

The septic tank has been completed and connected up with the disposal bed and the grounds have been levelled and graded.

As I know it is the intention to complete this school as soon as possible and at the very latest within the fiscal year, the heating and plumbing will be the only work that will cause delay. The local contractors do not appear to be interested as is plainly shown. My suggestion would be to have Mr. S. J. R. McMillan, the foreman carpenter on the present work, go ahead and install the plumbing and heating under the same arrangement as he is presently employed. The tinsmithing could be let out on order and if any materials are not readily obtainable, I could contact the Department for assistance. In this way the work could be proceeded with to completion without interruption. I also believe that costs could be kept down below the lowest tender. Mr. McMillan is an experienced contractor and has had considerable experience in contracting and we are fortunate to have obtained his services. During the past summer he has completed the remodelling of a two room school house for the Township of Ainwick. The work included the installation of a new heating plant and inside flush toilets. I have full confidence in his ability to complete this work satisfactorily.

If my suggestion is favourably received, may I have two copies of "Bill of Materials for forced warm air heating system" and two copies of "Bill of Materials for plumbing" for plan 865.

It would be preferable if in installing the heating system that an oil firing furnace be used as I have found considerable difficulty with keeping school at even temperatures, keeping grates in and ashes removed due to the dislike for routine of most of the janitors whose services we have been able to obtain. With the installation of oil heating equipment it is my belief that the services of a janitor could be disposed of and the children under the supervision of the teacher could carry out all of the remaining services without a great deal of difficulty in a school of this type.

V. M. EASTWOOD,
Superintendent,
Rice and Mud Lakes Agency.
December 20, 1948.

Mr. V. M. Eastwood,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
385 Water Street,
Peterborough, Ontario.

ALNWICK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

HEATING: By now, you will have received copy of purchase order No. 35781 of November 15, 1948, authorizing Messrs. Goodfellow and Dougherty, 379 Water Street, Peterborough, to supply and install the forced air heating system at the above school, in accordance with specifications and plan 865.

As discussed with you by Long Distance several days ago, we will have to delay the installation of an oil burning unit in this furnace for the present.

PLUMBING: We will anticipate receiving from you a requisition for the bath, toilets, etc., required and will arrange with the Departmental Purchasing Agent for delivery of these. We concur in your recommendation that Mr. McMillan install the plumbing and that arrangements be made for local purchase of the pipe required. It is understood that vouchers covering these accounts will not exceed $100.00.

Re: Painting Alnwick Indian Day School

With reference to Departmental letters file 377-5(E) of November 15 and December 20, I endeavoured to contact Mr. Richard Surerus by telephone but was told that he was in Florida. As I was anxious to have someone lined up to commence painting on completion of the carpentry work and installation on the heating plant, I wrote to Mr. Surerus on December 30, and finally received a reply on the 16th of January stating that he would like to contract for it by the hour supplying his own painting equipment and at the hourly rate of $1.25 for himself and $1.10 for his help. I again wrote him on the 19th of January stating that I would require a firm tender for the work in accordance with the specifications, giving him until the first of February for a reply. He does not appear to be interested as no reply has been received.

A Mr. Walter Houghton of Harwood has submitted his tender for $550.00 and I attach his letter to this effect. This is for labour only less materials which were purchased from Scarfe & Company.

Further, I have received a tender, which I attach, from Mr. Walter Down of Roseneath. I would recommend Mr. Down for the work as he is a veteran whereas the others are not. He is qualified to do the work and has had considerable experience. He resides at Roseneath and is presently working as a carpenter on the work. I believe him to be acceptable by all concerned. An additional consideration is that all the interior painting could be completed before the final laying of the hardwood floors and they could be then stained and finished on completion. If he is successful in the tender, he will employ Clifford Smoke, another veteran and a member of the Alnwick Band.

I consider that $550.00 is a reasonable amount for painting the interior and exterior three coats of paint in accordance with the specifications.

V. M. EASTWOOD,
Superintendent,
rice and Mud Lakes Agency.
Ottawa, February 14, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Painting - Almerrick Indian Day School.

On November 9, 1948, we received a memorandum from Mr. A.G.L. Adams, advising that we were to contact Mr. Richard Surerus of Rosencrath, Ontario, concerning the painting contract for this new school.

We have now received a self-explanatory letter from Mr. Indian Superintendent Eastwood, reading as follows:

"With reference to Departmental letters, file 377-5 (E) of November 15 and December 20, I endeavoured to contact Mr. Richard Surerus by telephone but was told that he was in Florida. As I was anxious to have someone lined up to commence painting on completion of the carpentry work and installation on the heating plant, I wrote to Mr. Surerus on December 30, and finally received a reply on the 16th of January stating that he would like to contract for it by the hour supplying his own painting equipment and at the hourly rate of $1.25 for himself and $1.10 for his help. I again wrote him on the 19th of January stating that I would require a firm tender for the work in accordance with the specifications, giving him until the first of February for a reply. He does not appear to be interested as no reply has been received.

"A Mr. Walter Houghton of Harwood has submitted his tender for $550.00 and I attach his letter to this effect. This is for labour only less materials which were purchased from Scarfe & Company.

"Further, I have received a tender, which I attach, from Mr. Walter Down of Rosencrath. I would recommend Mr. Down..."
for the work as he is a veteran whereas the others are not. He is qualified to do the work and has had considerable experience. He resides at Roseneath and is presently working as a carpenter on the work. I believe him to be acceptable by all concerned.

An additional consideration is that all the interior painting could be completed before the final laying of the hardwood floors and they could be then stained and finished on completion. If he is successful in the tender, he will employ Clifford Smoke, another veteran and a member of the Alnwick Band.

"I consider that $550.00 is a reasonable amount for painting the interior and exterior three coats of paint in accordance with the specifications."

I attach, for your information, the tenders from Mr. Houghton and Mr. Down and also a letter from Mr. Surorus. Could we please be advised as to what action should be taken in this regard, in view of Mr. Adams' previous memorandum.

Encl.

Director.

Alnwick Indian Day School - file 377-5(E)

The construction of the above school is now nearing completion. There remains to be completed the installation of railings for the stairway, some strapping on the ceilings, the installation of the balance of the spiral balances on the windows which were short shipped and the laying of the hardwood floor, all of which should be completed within the next week to ten days. This will complete the carpentry work.

Heating

The heating plant has been installed complete less one thermostat which has been ordered, less hooking up the fan to the electric power and the installation of the registers on the heat outlets which will be installed on the completion of the painting. The furnace is now in operation and the building is fully heated.

Plumbing

All pipes have been connected and the plumbing fixtures are on the premises for installation on the completion of the laying of floors and linoleum.

The bill of materials for the school does not call for the supplying of a pump and compression tank with the well to supply the water system. This would appear to be a separate item. The well is forty-five feet deep and is located about twenty feet north of the school. I have had it bailed out and it requires cleaning out for about another two feet which will make the maximum lift from the bottom of the well forty-seven feet.

The specifications and bill of material under the plumbing contract calls for a thirty gallon hot water boiler. This will require a heating element or source. I would recommend that a Hydro Electric Power Commission electric heater be installed at a cost of approximately thirty dollars to include heater, asbestos jacket, thermostat control, cable, labour and inspection. The cost of operating this heater is
forty-nine cents per hundred watt per month which would be $1.96 less
the usual ten per cent off for prompt payment, $1.77 per month. Total
cost per annum $21.24. I would recommend this type of hot water heater
as I do not think a jacket heater would heat it for this amount and
would certainly not be as dependable. The teacher's residence does not
require a coal heater and would best be served by an electric stove
which by arrangement would be the responsibility of the teacher tenant
or by arrangement otherwise. I would like to be advised in this
particular matter as Mr. John Loukes, the present teacher, would like
to know whether he would be required to buy a stove or not.

Painting
I wrote on February 4th and 18th, this agency file 6-3(25) requesting
instructions in regard to painting and as this can be started immediately
I am anxiously awaiting instructions.

In purchase order 83552 which was placed prior to settling the matter
of the exterior finishing of the school, twelve gallons of white exterior
lead and oil paint, first grade, was supplied at a cost of $59.40 which
is not now needed as insulating brick was used as the exterior covering. There
may be some additional supplies required and I would request authority
to exchange a portion of this for other materials should this occur, if
not, for a credit in this amount. I would only know after painting had
commenced. It will take approximately three weeks to complete the paint-
ing allowing sufficient time between coats. If I had the instructions
in regard to painting, the school should be completed within approximately
three weeks from the date of notice.

Electric wiring
This has been completed and has passed the hydro inspector's inspection.
Due to the short shipment of one control, the furnace is operating without
the fan but this can be hooked up as soon as the control is received.

In changing from plan 837 on which most of the materials were purchased
to plan 865 and providing a larger building there has been very little
surplus material but there will be some surplus, for instance some insul-
bric siding (jasper black), possibly some insulation, but there will be
very little lumber, no cement. On the other hand the extras have been
kept to a minimum. A list of this surplus will be made and forwarded
with a request for directions as to disposal.

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

Re: Alnwick Indian Day School

With reference to your letter of March 17th, 1949, I am returning the correspondence which has been received from Mr. Richard Surerus.

With reference to your request for information, I submit the following:

(1) Size of school, accommodation and type of construction.

One-room school with a teacher's residence, accommodation for approximately forty children. A new plan (No. 865) was followed providing electricity in the teacherage and school; full plumbing and toilets for both pupils and teacher.

(2) Were tenders called? If not, why not?

Tenders were not called. It was originally intended to erect this school in the summer of 1947, and Indian Superintendent Eastwood made extensive enquiries in the vicinity of the Alnwick Reserve, and wrote us as follows in a letter dated August 23rd, 1947:

"Although it is generally known in the vicinity of the Alnwick Reserve that a school is to be built on this reserve, I have had no other requests for plans and specifications by builders in order to..."
submit tenders. Mr. McMillan is the only builder to my knowledge living near this locality, and is well recommended. I have spoken to several small contractors, but they are so taken up with work they are not interested in seeing the plans."

The tender that Mr. McMillan submitted at that time on the old plan 837 was considered too high, and in a letter dated September 26th, 1947, Superintendent Eastwood was informed that we were not prepared to consider Mr. McMillan's tender.

(3) If tenders were not called, how was construction undertaken?

(4) Who recommended Mr. McMillan, and was the usual Ministerial approval secured for his employment?

(5) What rate of pay has Mr. McMillan received and was he given a free hand with respect to the employment of labour?

It was necessary to revote funds in 1948-49, and on June 8th, 1948, Superintendent Eastwood was written in part as follows:

"We have found that contractors are reticent to forward firm tenders for the erection of these schools. Within the last two months we have been able to engage a number of foremen-carpenters across the country who are willing to supervise the erection of this building using local and Indian labour. The usual rate for their services is $1.50 per hour. Under such a day labour plan, the Department buys all the necessary materials from a standard bill which we have prepared. It is usually necessary to arrange for sub-contracts for the electricity, plumbing, etc. Such a plan also provides for the employment of a certain amount of Indian labour and we have been quite satisfied with the type of school thus erected. As you know, the drawings and specifications are very clear and concise and have presented no difficulties..."
for other carpenters who have erected this building. Do you know of any such carpenter who would be willing to undertake the erection of this building under such terms. If so, I would ask that you advise the Department. I attach a copy of the standard bill of materials which we supply in such cases."

In reply to that communication, Superintendent Eastwood forwarded a letter from Mr. McMillan offering to supervise the erection of the Alnwick School as foreman-carpenter at the rate of $1.50 per hour. His name was submitted to the Minister's Office in a memorandum dated August 6th, 1948, and the employment of Mr. McMillan was approved. It will be noted from our letter of June 8th, 1948 (quoted above) that Superintendent Eastwood was advised that local and Indian labour could be employed.

(6) Were the materials required for the construction purchased through the departmental purchasing agent?

With the exception of gravel, stone and sand, and a few other items, materials required were purchased through the departmental purchasing agent. P.C. 4510 dated October 5th, 1948, authorized the acceptance of the tender of the Peterborough Lumber Company, for supplying lumber and millwork.

(7) Approximate cost of the school.

The approximate cost of the school is slightly over $19,000.00. Plan 837 (with no plumbing or electricity) is costing now between $18,000.00 and $19,000.00 to build. We, therefore, feel that the cost of this building, complete with the extra services mentioned above, is fair and reasonable. This has a full basement, convertible for use as a second classroom when the pupilage warrants it. This is the first and only school built according to this particular plan.
I may add that in connection with the painting of the school, in which Mr. Surerus was particularly interested, I attach copy of a memorandum forwarded to the Minister's Office on February 14th, 1949, and also a copy of the reply we received dated February 22nd, 1949.

Bernard F. Neary,

Alnwick Indian Day School

Reference Departmental File No. 377-5(El), work on installing the water system at the above school was suspended while the frost was coming out of the ground. Conditions are now favourable to resumption of the work.

The well is approximately seventy feet deep and large enough to take a 36" cement tile. At present it is filled with water to about 15' from the top. This has filled in a three weeks period since the well was last bailed out. Part may be surface water but not all. When the last ten feet was dug out there was evidence of a flow of water which I believe should be adequate for the purpose. Over one week-end with frost in the ground, no melting, there was an accumulation of approximately 1200 gallons.

At the site is sufficient 36' tile for 45' of well, which has been paid for. This size of tile is difficult to obtain. I do not know of any local supply available under a 2 month or longer delivery. The tile are 2½' deep. For the 25' and one extra for top, eleven would be required. As these tile cost about $7.50 a piece there would be considerable saving in using 8" tile for the 27½' required. The top of the 36" tile could be covered with a reinforced tile cover with the 8" tile cemented in. The 8" tile would carry the intake and discharge pipes for the pump. The 8" tile is 30" long and cost $1.40 each. This would permit installation and withdrawal of the pipe for repair also ventilation for the well.

Ottawa, May 11, 1915.

Sir,

Rev Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant in reference to transfer of land for the re-building of residence at Alderville, Ont., for missionary teacher, with sketch plan inclosed, and in reply to say that the Department will require this lot to be of sufficient depth in the rear so that a stable and carriage-house may be erected at such distance from the house that no nuisance will be caused by proximity. In other respects the site and dimensions are satisfactory.

The survey of land will be undertaken by the Department's surveyors.

The Department is prepared to advertise for tenders for the erection of the building as soon as the preliminary arrangements will warrant such, so that the building may be completed and ready for occupation before the cold weather approaches.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. John Arnup, B.A.,

Ottawa, 6th October, 1923.
Ottawa, October 10, 1922.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report the necessity for providing residential accommodation for the teacher of the day school on the reserve of the Mississaugas Indians of Alnwick, in the county of Northumberland in the province of Ontario.

In order to provide the necessary accommodation, it has been found upon investigation by the architect of the Department that by an expenditure of $1500 for repairs a disused building on the reserve can be utilized as a suitable residence for the school teacher, and the Indians of the band have expressed their willingness to have the expenditure made from their funds.

The undersigned would recommend that under Section 89 of the Indian Act authority be given for the above mentioned expenditure being made from the capital at the credit of the Mississaugas of Alnwick, which amounts to $91,930.21.

[Signature]

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The recommendation herewith is for approval of an expenditure of $1500 from Alnwick band capital on repairs to a disused building in order to provide a residence for the teacher of the Indian day school on the reserve.

Some years ago the school teacher lived in the building which it is now proposed to utilize and which has been in disuse for some years. The practice of leaving it to the teacher to find quarters in Indian houses or elsewhere—which has obtained for some time—is not satisfactory. To build a new residence would be too costly; and upon the architect of the Department being sent to the reserve recently he found that the "old mission house" on the reserve could be made into a suitable residence for the teacher at a cost of $1500 for alterations and repairs. The Indians themselves, who object to a sufficient expenditure to provide a new residence, are willing that $1500 be taken from their funds (though they have not specified that it be taken from their capital) to repair the old mission building.

Section 89 provides for expenditures of band capital on the construction and repair of school buildings, etc., without the consent of the Indians.

These Indians have $91,930.21 at the credit of their capital accounts.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, October 10, 1922.
The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs reporting the necessity for providing residential accommodation for the teacher of the day school on the reserve of the Mississagwa Indians of Alnwick, in the county of Northumberland in the province of Ontario; that in order to provide the necessary accommodation, it has been found upon investigation by the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs that by an expenditure of $1500 for repairs a disused building on the reserve can be utilized as a suitable residence for the school teacher, and the Indians of the band have expressed their willingness to have the expenditure made from their funds.

The Superintendent General recommends that under Section 89 of the Indian Act authority be given for the above mentioned expenditure being made from the capital at the credit of the Mississagwas of Alnwick, which amounts to $91,930.21.

The Board concur in the above recommendation and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

I beg to enclose herewith receipt vouchers in duplicate in favour of the parties mentioned therein together with a statement of same covering an expenditure for labour and material for the Mission House on the Almworth Indian Reserve amounting to $1179.85 exceeding in extent by $179.85. Kindly send me a cheque for $218.75 in order that I may pay this back to the Bank and pay Franklin and Marsden.

The carpenters are working at the wood shed now, the house being about ready for the painter who will commence painting and papering next week as soon as the plaster is dry enough.

On October 18th, 1922, an Order-in-Council was passed authorizing the expenditure of Capital Funds to the amount of $1500.00 for repairs and alterations to the Mission House on Alnwick Reserve.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 18th, regarding the Mission House on Alnwick Reserve.

Sir:

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-2-1 of February 23rd, with reference to the grand-children of Ben French of the Chippewa Band and will explain in detail the conditions regarding these children being on the Reserve.

Clara French, daughter of Ben, married a white man named William Peterson of London, Ont., about 12 years ago and left the reserve and resided in London. From this union were born three children: William, now aged 12 yrs.; Clara, aged 10 yrs.; and Gilbert, aged 8 yrs. Mrs. Peterson died on January 15th, 1932, and Peterson continued to keep house in London with the help of a housekeeper until May. Conditions at the home became bad and the Children's Aid Society of London offered to take the children to which step the grandparents objected and the father continued to keep the children until the summer holidays of 1932, and in July of that year the two older children were taken to the grandparents' home on the Chippewa Reserve, where they have remained ever since. In November of 1932 the father of the children did take to the French home the younger child and left him there, as he was out of employment and was unable to keep the child. Since then the children have been at the home of Ben French; the father has only contributed the sum of $3.00 towards their keep, and they have not seen him since November last. Peterson has always resided in London but owns no property there and has always rented; he has household furniture only.

In September last the grandparents sent the two older children to a white school at Christina, which is only a mile distant and the trustees of the school complained about them and they were removed from the school, although French advises me that he paid for their books and was agreeable to pay school tax to allow them to continue and still is agreeable to pay any tax necessary.

While recently visiting Back Settlement school the teacher informed me that two of these children came to the school which is over two miles from the French home and the teacher asked...
me my opinion as to allowing them to attend and I informed her that as her school was crowded for seats at the present time and as these children were of white parentage I considered that they could not be stopped from attending the Christina school under the circumstances and that as her school had not the accommodation they should be advised to attend the white school, where I knew there was plenty of room. I might add that a couple of Indians also complained to me that these children being white should not be allowed on the reserve. I also seen one of the trustees of the Christina school and talked the matter over with him and informed him of the parentage of these children and that in my opinion they could not be stopped from attending their school, which is so close at hand.

While Ben French is a very good Indian and entirely self-supporting, he did not ask the consent of the Indian Council of the Band or the permission of the Department to allow these children to reside on the reserve in the first place as he should have done and in view of the fact the Department has approved of the removal of other children such as these (Julia Fisher's grand-children, your file 39007 of March 20th 1932 and Lucy Fisher's adopted grand-child, your file 102-7 of Jan 27-33) and in view of the fact that paragraph 3 of your circular 102-1 of July 2nd, 1931 criticized Agents for allowing these outsiders to remain on the Indian Reserves and also in view of the fact that the Children's Aid Society offered help for these children, I would consider that they should be removed from the reserve in the Spring and their father made responsible for their support and keep, for while Ben French can and will support them properly providing he has his health, by allowing them to remain will mean they will to some extent be charges of the Department for schooling and medical attention.

The number of Indian children attending Back Settlement school taxes the seating at this school and there is no other Indian school close that these children can attend and if they remain with their grandparents I consider that they should attend the nearest white school, as many other Indian children do who live off the reserve or on the boundaries of a Reserve.

Dear Sir:

I am directed by this Committee to bring to your attention a matter concerning a school on the Indian Reserve at Muncey in Middlesex, known as the Back Settlement school.

This reserve, as you know, has more than 1400 persons living on it, all of whom are Protestants. In the school in question there is employed a teacher—Miss Howe—who is a Roman Catholic. I understand that she has been employed for some time and received her appointment on the recommendation of the Indian Agent Mr. Moore.

From the wording of the Indian Act, this is entirely irregular, as it specifically states that the teacher will be of the religion of the band.

I am requested to respectfully urge that this condition be remedied, and a Protestant teacher placed in this school.

Might we add too, that this is the second complaint of this nature within a few years, a teacher being replaced about two years ago in the Oneida section of the reserve. We do not know the religion of the Indian Agent, but surely some care should be exercised in appointing agents and teachers whose religion is different from every one residing on this reserve. We are informed that the newly appointed R.C.M.P. officer is a Roman Catholic. If that is so, we feel that it is only fair and just to submit that on a reserve where not one soul in 1482 is other than a Protestant, no one but a Protestant should be employed in these official positions.

Yours very truly,

L.H. Saunders,
Secretary.

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of the 19th instant, enclosing copy of a letter received from Mr. L. H. Saunders, Secretary, Grand Orange Lodge Ontario West.

In August, 1929, Indian Agent Moore submitted three applications that he had received for appointment as teacher at the Back Settlement Indian Day School in the Caradoc Agency (Electoral District of Middlesex West). One of these applicants was Miss Helen M. Howe and the Department chose her as being the best qualified for the position. Mr. Saunders is under a wrong impression when he considers her appointment was recommended by Indian Agent Moore. Miss Howe's application for appointment did not state her religion and it was not until some years afterwards that the Department was informed that she is a Roman Catholic.

Miss Howe began duties at the Back Settlement Indian Day School on September 1st, 1929, and has taught continuously since that time. Reports received from the Public School Inspector, who visits the Back Settlement School twice a year, have always been
The Honourable the Superintendent General

very favourable. Under these circumstances, the Department has not considered it necessary to dispense with her services.

Referring to the third paragraph of Mr. Saunders' letter, it is presumed that he refers to Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act. I would point out that this section does not apply in the case of the appointment of teachers to Indian schools.

It has always been the practice to appoint a Protestant teacher when the Indians of the Band are Protestant and a Catholic teacher when the Indians are Catholic.

In view of Miss Howe's long and satisfactory service, it is felt that she is entitled to some consideration, and I would therefore recommend that her services be retained until the end of the present academic year, viz., June 30, 1937, when she could be given due notice that her services would not be required after that date. If she was dismissed immediately, the pupils would, no doubt, be handicapped by a change of teacher in the middle of the term.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

Referring to your enquiry regarding Miss Helen M. Howe, teacher of the Back Settlement Indian Day School, I would point out that in August, 1929, Indian Agent Moore submitted three applications that he had received for appointment as teacher of this school. One of these applicants was Miss Howe, and the Department chose her as being the best qualified for the position. Agent Moore had not made a definite recommendation regarding which of the three applicants should be chosen.

Miss Howe's application for appointment did not state her religion and it was not until some years afterwards that the Department was informed that she is a Roman Catholic.

While the Indian children attending this school are Protestants, none of the Protestant churches takes any special interest in the school.

Regarding religious instruction, our Programme of Studies for Indian Day Schools prescribes "Scriptural Reading", "The Ten Commandments", "The Lord's Prayer" and the "Life of Christ". As far as we are aware, Miss Howe has strictly followed our instructions in this regard.

Public School Inspector Sexton visits the Back Settlement School twice each year. The last inspection was on September 23rd, 1936, at which time he reported regarding the teacher as follows: "A successful teacher of Indian children. Miss Howe is doing good work here. The general management and discipline of this school are of the highest order. The pupils are obedient, but very shy. The teacher has done much to improve their manner and habits".

The Back Settlement School is in the Caradoc Agency (Electoral District of Middlesex West). The Indian Agent is Mr. A. D. Moore, Muncey, Ont. In addition to this school, there are five other day schools in this Agency, at each of which a Protestant teacher is employed.

Dear Sir:

In the past, the Day Schools of Caradoc Agency have been operating on Eastern Standard Time. In view of recent Government regulations whereby Eastern Daylight Saving Time is compulsory throughout Ontario, I would wish to be advised if the Caradoc Agency Indian Day Schools should change to Daylight Saving Time or still continue on Standard Time.

The Department is no doubt aware that time means nothing to an Indian, and in spite of all the ingenuity of the various teachers, the Indian children are habitually late in arriving at school even when Standard time is in force.

If Daylight Saving Time is to be made compulsory at the Indian Day Schools, the routine of the school will be upset by children who come late.

In my opinion it would be wise to leave the matter as to whether the schools operate on Daylight Saving or Standard Time to the discretion of the teacher, who would be in a better position to decide which time would work most satisfactorily in each section of the Reserve. Kindly advise if the Department approves of granting the teachers permission to operate on whichever time he or she finds most suitable.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

On the reopening of schools after the summer holidays, there was some doubt, owing to a scarcity of teachers, as to whether all schools would be open. REPORT ON CARADOC INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1946.

Schools:

All schools were visited during the month, and after a general discussion with the teachers it was thought that the 24th of May, not being a holiday, could be used educationally in a combined display of the work done by the boys and girls of the three Oneida schools and invite the parents. Oneida No. 1 was used and a great crowd turned out. I am sure the parents appreciated not only the work of their children but the efforts of the Rev. Mr. Joblin and their teachers.

During the afternoon Mr. Joblin officially announced his retirement as minister of the Oneida United Church, regretted leaving the boys and hoped that some way would be found to carry on with the Manual Training classes that had been established during him 1945. On behalf of Mr. Hoey, the Welfare Branch and the Department of Indian Affairs, I thanked him most sincerely for his interest and valuable time and instruction given to the boys and the schools in general, and hoped that they would all remember Mr. Joblin, not only as their spiritual adviser but, as a gentleman who had given unstintingly of his time in an endeavour to further their education whether it be in play or work. The day finished with refreshments and the teachers deserve great credit for their efforts. I am sure they felt repaid by the large number of parents who came out to show their appreciation. I took a few snaps during the afternoon which are being submitted under separate cover. They will help you visualize the work that is being done.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

General Report of Conditions and Activities at the Caradoc Agency, for the Six Month Period ending June 20, 1945.

Schools and Education

During visits to the various Indian Day Schools one is again impressed with the closeness of the tie-up between schools and general road conditions. One could condemn all schools as inaccessible for at least four months of every year. Attendance, as reported, at the end of each month might appear, and is sometimes disappointing but one Spring and one Fall is sufficient to make one sympathize with pupils and teachers.

It has been said, and reported many times, that our schools are well-managed and progress in academic studies reaches a good standard of educational requirement. There is, however, and I have mentioned it in previous reports, plenty of scope and pupil material for advancement in Vocational and Manual Training. Many of our teachers today are apt to place this type of training as a "fillein," or a nuisance, which tends to clutter up the class-room. In our rural schools it does perhaps present a problem; this is because the teacher in her, or his, endeavour to supervise seven or eight grades in one room is annoyed and distracted to suddenly hear the screech of a saw, or the pounding of a hammer, or "Teacher, Johnny has cut his finger!" or "Johnny has his thumb with a hammer!" This type of education should not find its place in the general class-room; neither should a teacher, trained in academics and teaching all grades, be expected to supervise Manual Training.

Some of our most prominent educationists of the day have taken time out to stress the necessity of Manual Training in the changing curriculums of basic education. However, to introduce and set up a workable plan under our present teacher system, and present day buildings, would create a major problem. In the near future it is hoped that a new school will be built, centrally located, for the Chippewa and the Muncey Bands. It should be a model school with academic class-rooms, Manual Training class-room, Vocational and Home Economics class-rooms and recreational basement; each fully equipped (over)
and under the supervision of qualified teachers. There should be a teachers' residence separate from the school, and spacious grounds for school sports and inter-school competitions; and, above all, good roads to get to it. It should not be a question of cost, it should be a question of education.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.
Muncey, Ontario,
June 27, 1946.

It is recalled that Dr. Moore on his return to Ottawa from this Agency, about three months ago, contacted officials of the Ontario Department of Health and arranged for an X-Ray Survey of the Indians of the Caradoc Agency.

The writer feels that the arrangement is worthwhile in that it will determine chest conditions, and provide valuable information to the Agency's medical personnel. The program demands of organizing competent assistance has given this understaffed, hectic Office many a headache and much work. In fact I am wondering, if the Medical Service of Indian Welfare as to remain separated from the parent, and under dual administration, whether it would not be advisable to arrange with some eminent psychiatrist for a survey in an endeavour to determine the I.Q.'s and stages of mentality likely to evolve from such confusion. Our Indian Day School teachers have again rallied to our side; this time during their holidays. We are therefore hoping that the Indians will avail themselves of the opportunity of the free service provided. There is however, one point which I would like to stress. We are apt to use the willing horse too often and our teachers feel, and rightly so, that their services should be recognized in some small financial way. They are canvassing the Reserves for the purpose of tabulating families, and also giving two days of their holidays to help with the clerical work during the days of the clinic. I would suggest that they be allowed mileage for their cars, also two days' pay at the regular teachers' salary prevailing.

Geo. W. Down,
