Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Back Settlement Indian Day School

At Mr. Pratt's request, Major Clark recently inspected the one-room provincial school at Caradoc, with a view to having it moved on to the Caradoc Reserve for use as a school building.

He reports that this is a large (40 x 32) heavy, old-fashioned building, with an interior metal finish. It is approximately 3 miles from the Back Settlement, Caradoc Reserve, where we require the school.

Consideration had to be given, not only to the price of the building and the cost of moving, but also the cost of re-establishing the school at the new site. Therefore, we consulted the Lands and Development Services Branch and were advised that a building of this age would not likely stand being moved such a distance unless we were prepared to practically rebuild it on the new site. The vertical members are almost certain to be warped in moving and we are almost certain to have to expend a considerable sum in order to have the building made fit for use as a school.

In addition to these factors, we would not end up with a particularly good school. If you will refer to the attached photographs, you will note that the windows are few and therefore that fenestration would be much lower than
minimum requirements. This, of course, would necessitate putting in extra windows and would create new problems and expense.

In view of the above, my Superintendent of Education does not recommend the purchase of this building.

We are now investigating the possibility of moving one of the former RCAF buildings from Fingal, Ontario. We have used similar buildings on the Six Nations Reserve and have found them satisfactory. They are light, well constructed and easy to adapt for school purposes. If the Crown Assets Allocation Committee does not declare these RCAF buildings surplus, then I would recommend that we proceed with our original plan of building a new school. The Archbishop of Huron has just written in, requesting that we vacate the basement of the Anglican Church which we are presently using as a temporary school.

Director,

Ottawa, June 17th, 1925.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing an application from Miss May Dingman for the position as teacher of the Back Settlement Indian Day School, and stating the qualifications which she possesses. This salary includes a special amount of $50 towards the cost of her transportation to and from the school to her boarding house. She should arrange for the payment of the transportation cost from the salary allowed.

We hope that Miss Dingman will meet with every success in her work at this school, and I shall be pleased if you will give her every assistance you can. Please inform her of her appointment and the date upon which it is expected she will begin duties.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 25, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, informing the Department of the illness of Miss Helen Howe, teacher of the Back Settlement Indian Day School, and that it will be necessary for her to be absent from her duties for a period of from four to six weeks. The illness of Miss Howe is regretted.

In this connection I have to say, in order that the school will not remain closed, the temporary appointment of Mr. Glen Marshman is approved until such time as Miss Howe is able to resume work. Mr. Marshman will be allowed salary for the period he teaches, at the rate of $95 per teaching month, less 10% during the present fiscal year. You should arrange with him to begin duties at the earliest possible date - it being understood that his services will terminate when Miss Howe is ready to return.

The Department will continue payment of Miss Howe's salary until November 15th, by which time it is hoped she will have regained her health. When the return of attendance for the current quarter is being prepared, it should show clearly the dates between which Miss Howe was absent. When she resumes duties, you might forward a statement showing the dates between which Mr. Marshman taught and the number of teaching days, when a cheque in payment of the salary due him for his services could be forwarded.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Runsey, Ont.
Sir;-

Mr. Glen Marshman was appointed as temporary teacher and assumed duty on the 31st day of October and continued on duty for the full teaching month of November and therefore has one month and one days salary due him at the rate of $86.50 per month. Mr. Marshman's cheque could be mailed to him at Melbourne, Ont.

Secretary,

Ottawa, 23rd February, 1900.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to state that a resolution has been passed by the Chippewa Band of the Thames in favour of an expenditure up to $425 being made from their capital—which amounts to $78,160.17—on the erection of a new school-house to replace the old one known as the Back Settlement School, on their reserve in the County of Middlesex, Ontario.

The Indian Agent reports that the old school-house is in a very dangerous condition and is not worth repairing.

The undersigned would therefore respectfully recommend that, under Sec. 139 of the Indian Act (as added thereto by Sec. 11 of Chap. 32, Vic. 57-58), authority be given for the expenditure of $425 from the capital at the credit of the band above mentioned on the erection of the building referred to.

[Signature]

Specifications for a School House to be built on the Carador Indian Reserve.

Description. A one story frame building on a stone foundation 30 ft by 22 ft, with a porch 8 ft by 10 ft. Height from floor to ceiling 12 ft.

Foundation. Plain rubble masonry 16 in. thick 3 ft. 6 in. high; 1 ft. above ground and 2 ft 6 in below. The outside walls are to be pointed above the ground. A centre wall to support the floor joists 2 ft high; 1 ft above ground, and 1 ft below, is to be built down the centre of the building. 2 in planking to be laid along the tops of all walls, and bedded in mortar to receive the joists.

Ventilators. Four iron ventilators are to be placed in the outer wall; two on each side of the building.

Joists. Floor joists 2" X 10"; set at 2 ft centres. One row of herring-bone braces to be put down through the centre of joists on each side of the centre wall. Ceiling joists are to be 2" X 8"; set at 2 ft centres.

Flooring. To be 1½ in dressed, tongued and grooved and blind nailed.

Studding. 2" X 4" at 2 ft centres; double at all windows, doors and corners.

Wall Plates. 2" X 4" double.

Walls. Outside to be of one inch rough boarding, tar paper and drop siding. Inside lath and plaster; two coats hard finish, except under wainscoting.

Wainscoting. To be put on the lathing after it has received one coat of plaster. To be of double beaded sheeting, 4 ft high, well nailed to studding and lathing.

Ceiling. Lath and plaster; two coats hard finish. A manhole 2 ft by 3 ft fitted with a cover, is to be placed between the joists in the ceiling in the centre of the building.

Roof.
Roof.

Rafters to be 2" X 6" at 2 ft centres; braces 1" X 8" to be well nailed on the rafters half way up. To be covered with rough boarding, tar paper and shingles 4½" to the weather; surmounted with weather boards and roll. The eaves and cornice to be plainly finished with dressed one inch stuff.

Perch.

The foundation, joists, flooring and walls are to be the same as the main building. The rafters for the roof 2" X 4" without ceiling joists; braced half way up with 1" X 8" braces; these with the ends of the rafters will form the ceiling. Ceiling to be lathed and plastered with two coats hard finish; The roof to be covered the same as the main building.

Belfry.

A plain belfry is to be constructed on the roof at the front end of the building, as shown on the Plan. A hole for the bell rope is to be made through the roof, and the ceiling into the school room; both holes are to be boxed.

Chimney.

To be of well burnt brick one brick thick. To commence on the top of a cupboard 7 ft high. To be neatly finished above the roof, as shown on the Plan. To be well plastered within, and the portion in the schoolroom to be plastered on the outside, the same as the walls. A pipe hole with thimble, is to be placed in the schoolroom at two feet from the ceiling. To be fitted with a scot box and door.

Cupboard.

The sides and back of the cupboard are to be of 2" plank. It is to be fitted with shelves one foot apart, and provided with a plain battened door and lock.

Windows.

To be in two sashes; four lights 16 in square, in each sash. The upper sash fixed, the lower one to raise, to be fitted with proper fasteners. The gable is to have the circular window (or a square window) shown on the Plan, unglazed, and fitted with plain 1" X 6" slats.

Doors
Doors. The two doors required at the porch and school-room are to be 1½ in panelled doors 3 ft by 7 ft. The porch door is to have a fan light with two lights, as shown on the Plan.

Steps. To be built to the porch, as shown on the Plan.

Platforms. The portion of the floor shown as the platform on the Plan, is to be raised 6 inches.

Blackboards. The spaces on the rear wall between the cupboard and each side wall, are to be painted on the plaster, with prepared blackboard paint, 3 ft 6 in high, from the top of the wainscoting.

Painting. Two coats of good linseed oil and lead paint. The outside white, with neutral tint facings. All inside wood work, light drab.

General. A good, plain, substantial building, complete in every respect, is to be erected, of sound materials, and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent in charge of the Caradri Indian Reserve.

Ottawa, August 9, 1911.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to report that a new schoolhouse is required at Back Settlement on the Caradoc Indian Reserve, in the County of Middlesex, in the Province of Ontario. Tenders were called for the erection of this building, receivable up to noon of the 7th day of August, 1911, each offer to be accompanied by an accepted cheque for 10% of the amount of the tender.

Two tenders were received as follows:

Jas. Ballantine, Falconbridge, $3145.00
George McBeth, Strathroy, $3234.00

The Chippewa Band of Indians, on whose reserve this building is to be erected, have passed a resolution authorizing the expenditure of a sum not exceeding $1500.00 from the Capital Funds of their Band for the erection of this school-house. The Band have a sum of $24,473.42 to their credit and the undersigned recommends that the necessary authority be given to appropriate this amount as their contribution towards the erection of the building.

Money is available from the Vote for Indian Education (No. 267, Schedule C., Appropriation Act, 1911) to meet the balance of the cost of the erection of this building and the undersigned would also recommend that, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act, authority be given for awarding the
the contract for the erection of the school-house to Mr. James Ballantine for the sum of $3145.00.

(Signed) Wilfred Laurier

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Acceptance of tender for the erection of Back Settlement Indian School-house.

The school at Back Settlement has been held for some years in a church on the Reserve which is old and dilapidated and quite unsatisfactory for school purposes. There is an enrolment of over forty pupils at this school.

The Indians have authorized the expenditure of $1500.00 from their Capital Funds and the Department, recognizing the need for an up-to-date school-house on this reserve, have agreed to contribute the balance necessary from the vote for Indian Education.

The tender of Mr. James Ballantine is well below the estimated cost of the building called for by the plans and specifications and Mr. Ballantine is a practical builder who has done satisfactory work for the Department.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And James Ballantine, Builder and Contractor, of the town of Falconbridge, in the Province of Ontario (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame school-house to be erected at Back Settlement on the Caradoc Reserve.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the first day of November A.D. 1911.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of Three thousand, one hundred and forty-five dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. 2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any subcontractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

General Conditions

The Contractors are to give their personal supervision to the works, to furnish all necessary material, labour apparatus, scaffolding and utensils needful for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner, according to the drawings and these particulars prepared for the same.

All of the materials to be of the best of the sorts and qualities specified, and all to be sound and firm.

Should the Contractor introduce any material different from the sort or quality herein described, or meant to be implied, it shall be immediately removed at the contractors expense, at any time during the progress of the works.

The works are to be executed in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the true antent and meaning of plan and specification, and are intended to include everything requisite and necessary for the full and entire completion of the works without exception, notwithstanding every item necessarily involved in the works is not particularly mentioned and work shown and not specified and vice versa, are to be done as if both shown and specified.

At the completion the works are to be given up in a complete and undamaged state without exception.

Should any question arise as to the meaning of any portion of plan or specification, the same shall be referred to the determination of the officer in charge for the Department of Indian Affairs and whose decision shall be final without exception.
MASONRY.

Excavation.

Excavate to the depth, form and size as shown on foundation plan for foundation walls and piers. Excavation to be one foot larger than walls to allow for footing and pointing up of stone work. Excavate also for all drains to the depth and dimensions requisite to complete system as shown on plan.

The excavated earth will be stacked on the lot and leveled at completion to grade directed and required.

Stone Walls.

The stone foundation walls will have a footing course of large flat stone 6" thick and extending at least 6" on each side of walls above.

Carry up the walls marked stone of the dimensions and height shown on drawings of good quality local stones laid on their natural bed and well packed and hearted and flushed up each course with good mortar, and having at least three stones extending entirely through walls as bond stones to each yard of face work.

Pointing.

The outside of stone wall from grade line up will be neatly pointed up at completion with good cement mortar showing natural outline of stones.

Lime Mortar.

The mortar to be of the best quality composed of fresh burned grey lime, clean, sharp sand and water mixed in proportion of 3 parts of sand to 1 of lime and for cement mortar 2 parts of cement in addition.

Brick Work.
Brick work.

Build chimneys of good quality hard burned bricks, and carried through roof and finished as shown on drawings. The chimney to be well flushed up full each course and parged on inside of flues. All portions above roof to be laid in cement mortar.

Piers.

Build up as required brick stone or concrete piers of the height and dimensions shown on plan and to bed level in good mortar beams and all necessary plates on piers, walls &c. to carry joisting.

Beam Filling:

Beam fill from stone work to 18" above floorline with brick or stone mortar grout firmly rammed solid to steady framework. Beam fill also from plate to top of rafters with grout to exclude air at roof, all to be done in a good and satisfactory manner.

Drains.

The whole of the drainage system as required and shown on plan will be of the best salt glazed vitrified drain tile in sizes as marked, and to have all necessary bends, Y branches, traps and hand-hole traps, &c., required and necessary to complete system. All to be properly cemented at connections with best "Star Brand" Portland cement.
Carpentering and Joining

Sills

The sills for frame will be of four by six built up of two pieces of 2" by 6" in long lengths and well spike nailed together with 6" nails.

The sills will be evenly and firmly bedded level on stone foundation, as shown, and strongly and firmly secured together at corners.

Beams

The Beams will be of three pieces of 2" by 8" strongly nailed and bedded level on piers as shown.

Joists

The joists for ground floor will be of 2" by 12" ceiling joists of 2" by 6", set at 16" centres, bridged twice in length with 2" by 2" herring-boned bridging well nailed at each end with 2½" wire nails. The joisting to be firmly nailed to sills or plates at each end with 4" spike nails.

Frame Work

Build frame work of 2" by 6" scantling set at 16" centres, and having plate of 2" by 6" doubled in long lengths and well and firmly spike-nailed together and at all angles. The foot of studding to rest on sills and to be strongly spike-nailed to sills or plates and sides of joists with 4" nails.

Angle Bracing

Angle brace of 2" by 6" to be cut running from outside of wall to centre of ceiling on every wall, strongly-nailed to studding. The interior partitions will also be angle braced with 2" by 4" to further stiffen building.

Roof
Roof

The rafters will be of 2" by 6" set at 16" centres, framed at heel and well and strongly spike-nailed to plates and together with 4" spike nails.

Collar Ties

Provide and fix collar ties of 2" by 6" rim nailed to all rafters with hangers of 2" by 6" to ceiling joists, as shown, strongly spike-nailed at each end.

Rough Boarding

Cover all the outside frame and roof with good quality of narrow 7/8" spruce, pine, hemlock or fir shiplap boarding, well nailed, close jointed with at least two 3" nails to each board at each crossing of studding or rafter; the interior walls will be sheeted up with good quality of similar material on building paper before plastering.

Strapping

The interior of all exterior walls will be strapped with 7/8" spruce or pine strapping, strongly nailed to boarding at 16" centres.

Siding

The exterior walls will be covered with good building paper on shiplap and finished with a good quality of narrow dry pine weather board siding. The siding will be neatly fitted and well and strongly nailed to boarding with 2½" finishing nails.

Provide and fit at all angles 7/8" by 4" corner strip to which siding will finish and to be strongly nailed to framework as required.

Water Table

Provide and fit in position as shown, water table formed of 2" by 6" bevelled as required, strongly spike-nailed to framework.

Shingles
Shingles.

The roof to be covered with best quality of cedar shingles laid at 4½" to weather on double thickness of asbestos or tarred roofing felt and nailed with best quality of 1¾" steel shingle nails of Canadian manufacture. To have at least two nails to each 4" shingle.

Partitions.

The interior partitions will be of 2" by 4" studs set at 16" centres and to be well spike-nailed to head and foot plates with 4" nails.

Flooring.

Cover the ground floor joists with good quality of narrow rough spruce, hemlock, pine fir or cedar, laid diagonally and with close joints and well nailed to joisting with 3" nails. Cover this sub-floor with two thicknesses of oiled building or tarred roofing paper, then lay on ground floor joists good quality of narrow tongued and grooved 1¾" maple flooring, blind nailed with 3" finishing nails at each crossing of joist.

Trim.

All doors and windows to be trimmed with a neat 5" architraves, all to be hand smoothed and put on in a good and workmanlike manner.

Wainscoting.

Sheet up walls of class-room, cloak room and porch to a height of 4ft. 6in. with narrow V jointed pine sheeting, hand smoothed and strongly blind-nailed to walls. Provide and fix thereon suitable cap for the same.

Window Frames.

Provide and fix 7/8" pine box for window frames of size shown, having all necessary hanging stiles, blind stiles outside and inside lining, stops parting strips sills, subsills, back-band etc. complete and to have 1¾" sash double hung with best quality cast iron pulleys and silver lake sash cord and 1¾" storm sash to all windows. All to have suitable
suitable lifts and fasts put on complete.

Doors and Frames

Provide and fix suitable front porch and rear outside door frames formed of 2" pine rebated for 1½" door, having all necessary lining, oak sill etc., with back band for storm doors.

Exterior Doors

All exterior doors will be of good quality of dry 1½" white pine, panelled, morticed and tenoned; doors strongly framed and glued and fitted together. Panels to be bal-action molded and to be neatly fitted in place.

Interior Doors

All interior doors to be 2 ft. 10 in. by 6 ft. 10 in. 1½" thick of similar material and construction as outside doors excepting that the doors may be of cedar and the molding in panels which will be flush instead of bal-action molding.

All to be hung with good quality of 4" loose pin steel butts (three to exterior doors), and locked with a good quality of brass-faced and bolted door locks with necessary roses, plates etc., complete as required.

Inside Door Frames

Provide and fix 1½" pine jambs rebated for 1½" doors, where shown and required for all interior doors to be firmly fixed plumb and straight to walls and partitions.

Outside Steps

The outside steps to be built as shown, formed of 1½" treads 7/8 risers, 2" strings all to be well and firmly put together and nailed and to have strong carriage pieces supporting strings.

Porches

The porches will be built as shown and in every way constructed as specified for other portions of the building.
The contractor will put all necessary boards wood strips, etc., and do all cutting and trimming for ventilation, heating, etc., that may be required, also cutting required for other trades by reason of carpentry work.

NOTE. The portion of plastered wall marked for blackboard will have strapping placed at 8" centres instead of 16in. as specified for other portions of plastered walls.

METAL CEILINGS

Ceilings for the ground floor to be made with sheet metal of approved design and quality, having all the necessary borders and mouldings all to be put in the best manner and to the satisfaction of the officer in charge.

The ceiling to be sheeted with a heavy building paper before receiving the metal ceiling.
PLASTERING.

Lath all the walls partitions and first floor ceiling with good lath free from sap, laggé or loose knots 1\(\frac{1}{4}\)" wide and \(\frac{3}{8}\)" thick, nailed \(\frac{1}{2}\)" apart with steel lath nails and to break joints every 18".

CELENITE.

The first coat to be of celenite mixed in the proper proportions, of the best quality and to be put in the best manner all over the laggéd part of building.

The second coat is to be given when first coat is in good condition to receive it, and to be first quality plaster of Paris put up in the best manner.

The puttee (Plaster of Paris) to run at least two weeks before being used.

METAL ANGLE BEADS.

Metal angle beads to be used throughout the building when required and to be supplied and put up by the Contractor.

The plasterer must clean all wood work, floors, trim etc., before handing over the painters.

The whole of the work to be done in a workmanlike manner to the entire satisfaction of the Architect in charge.
BLACKBOARDS.

Provide and fix in place slate blackboards of the best quality, where shown, of the height and form required.

MOULDINGS FOR PICTURES.

The Contractor will provide and put in place in every room of the building, all around, at the height required a suitable moulding of approved quality to hang pictures etc.
TIN AND GALVANIZED IRON WORK

Provide and fix necessary cloak flashings over all windows and door frames and belfrey to prevent water getting behind frames, etc., The flashings to be of at least 6" width, and to be fixed in position before siding and shingle shingles are put on. Chimneys and ventilating flue will be stop flashed and cloak flashed also form and cover saddle at rear as shown.

GIRT.

Provide and fix 10" girt eavestrough to all cornices as required with same diameter conductor pipe. All to have necessary bends, elbows, rods and fasteners, etc. Conductor pipe will be kept 4" from face of walls.

All galvanized iron to be Keysight Queen's Head Brand, twenty eight (28) gauge galvanized iron.
PAINTING AND GLAZING

PAINTING

Paint all the exposed wood and iron work (interior and exterior), usually painted, three good coats of lead and oil, tinted as directed by officer in charge. The lead to be used will be best Canadian white lead, pure boiled linseed oil and pure turpentine as dryer. All work to be carefully knotted with best shellac before priming. When priming coat is dry, the work to be carefully stopped with best white lead coat of lead and oil, tinted as directed.

Woodwork requiring oil or stain, to be three coat work as directed for painting.

All floors throughout the building will be finished three coats of oil. First coat to be put on as soon as floors are laid and cleaned off.

GLAZING

The whole of the windows throughout the building to be glazed with double diamond English sheet glass of Pilkington manufacture, all to be free from winds/bends, air bubbles, etc. All glass to be sprigged, bedded and back and front puttied and left clean at completion.
HEATING AND VENTILATION

Provide and put in place where shown on plans a jacketed stove of approved size and quality having all the necessary apparatus to heat and ventilate the class room to the satisfaction of the officer in charge.

A 24" G.A.U. Galvanized Iron smoke pipe 10" diameter will be attached to the inside of the brick chimney with metal bands, 4" X 3" every four feet in height.

This pipe will be finished and attached to the cap of the chimney as will be directed.

The Contractor will also provide and make all the necessary connections to receive stove pipe and ventilation pipe.
Notes re Heating and Ventilating Br. Eastern School.

HEATING.

The heating will be furnished by a jacketed stove (for coal) as shown on plan, with a strong galvanized iron cover constructed with an iron frame and having the necessary openings, keys, etc.

The floor where this jacketed stove is to be placed will be first covered with a sheet of asbestos 4" and a galvanized iron base on top well nailed to the floor.

The fresh air will be admitted to the stove by two registers of large size, one connected to the outside of the building and the second taking air from the room, both having dampers for regulating supply.

VENTILATION.

In the front of the platform in the class-room a register of 6 x 15 will be placed from which a galvanized iron pipe will be connected to the side of the chimney two feet above its base and passing into the wall and well adjusted to the chimney.

A register of 15 inches in diameter will be placed in the centre of the ceiling of the class-room.

All registers to have borders and levers for opening and closing when necessary and to be black japanned.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Johnson in a report of his recent inspection of the Back Settlement Indian Day School, states that while the school buildings, as a whole, are in good repair, the roof of the schoolhouse leaks in two places; the storm door at the west end is broken off; the roof of the boys' water closet needs some repairs; the door of the girls' water closet needs a latch; there is one pane broken in one of the windows.

I have to request that you will be good enough to have the repairs made where required as above mentioned and all this work should be done at an early date so as to place the buildings in good condition before the weather gets too cold.

The work required should be performed at the lowest possible cost. Any material required should be purchased by you as cheaply as possible.

When the above repairs are completed you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Inspector also states that the walls of the class-room, cap-room and porch need renovating. You should furnish a report as to what is required in this regard and probable cost of having the work done. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Back Settlement Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the closets. January 14th, 1926

Attention of Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,

Sir,

I beg to submit the following survey of repairs and improvements to the six day schools on the Caradoc Reserve, which are required to put these schools in first-class condition.

Lower Muncey school requires painting on the outside, including closets and woodshed, also a small entrance gate is needed.

Back Settlement school also requires painting outside, and a lower step at entrance, the first step is about 15 inches from the ground, which is too high for the small children. Fence around playground requires stretching.

Bear Creek school, which was painted last year for the first time, should have one more coat of paint. Four coats were put on but the lumber was so spongey and dry that the first two coats were scarcely visible. One coat would make a good job of it and add to the life of the building. Closets require foundations jacked up and a small window in each closet. The roof on this school is very old and looks dilapidated; it is beginning to leak in several places, a new shingle roof is needed.

River Settlement school requires 24 new single seats, the present ones are very poor and have been wired together, in many cases to keep them from falling apart. This has been done to take as much service out of them as possible; new ones are really very much needed.

Oneida No.3 school requires painting both inside and out, parts of the outside lumber is showing signs of decay, especially the porch supports and window sills.
Some repairs to the plaster inside have been made from time to time and in painting these parts the walls have been made streaky.

Painted sign boards, with name of school, placed on each building, would add to the appearance and would cost only a nominal sum.

The cost of above repairs and improvements would be approximately one thousand dollars, which would be money well spent, adding to the life and appearance of the schools and to the progress of the Reserve.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

In reply to your letter No.7-2-5 of the 14th instant, with regard to painting Back Settlement Day School, also repairs to wood shed, moving the two closets and improving the water supply.

I beg to say that a tender for painting the school, inside and out, has been received from Neil McArthur, a local workman, who will do the job for $135.00 and supply all material. McArthur is a good workman and will make a satisfactory job of the painting.

With regard to closets, I do not think the location of these can be improved upon, the only change would be to bring them closer to the school, which in my opinion would not improve the appearance of the grounds, the children suffer no inconvenience from the short walk between closets and school.

The well from which the school water is obtained is not situated on the school property, but is just over the fence on the land located to Rufus Henry, who has given permission to use it. There is no pump the water being drawn up in a bucket, there is a good cement top and a pump can be purchased and installed at a cost of $30.00, if this were done the school would have a good supply of clean water at all times.

Attention of Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 7-2-5 of the 27th ultimo in connection with the Public School Inspector's report on the Back Settlement Day School.

I beg to say that this school requires to be painted both inside and outside and $300.00 was included in the 1927-8 estimates for this purpose. This school has never been painted, the frame is in good condition and if painted would last much longer, the inside has been painted but should be done again. The work of painting the outside and inside would be approximately $300.00 and would be well spent money.

There is no water supply on the grounds but there is an excellent well just over the fence from which the school has been supplied for years; a new pump was installed recently and a good supply of excellent drinking water is available at all times. I would not recommend digging a well on the grounds so long as the water can be obtained from the present source.

Ottawa, August 4, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, regarding the painting required to the interior and exterior of the Back Settlement Indian Day School building and giving an estimate of the cost.

In reply I beg to say, in view of your recommendation that this painting is necessary, the Department will approve of you arranging to have the work carried out by day labour, under the charge of a competent foreman. You should arrange for the purchase of all paints, oils, etc., required, obtaining competitive prices if possible and making the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should see that a good grade of paint, etc., is supplied. While a satisfactory job should be completed, it is expected you will see that all expense is kept as low as possible and that the estimate mentioned in your letter, viz., $200, will not be exceeded, if possible. The colours purchased will be left with you to decide. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept by you for all labour employed. If an advance to pay for the labour is required, you should make application for same in due time, stating the amount you require. Time sheets enclosed.

You should arrange to have this work begun as soon as possible, in order that it can be completed before the school re-opens after the summer holidays. When it has been finished, you should forward an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the paint and other material, and the time sheets, in duplicate, signed by the men employed and certified by yourself, covering the amount due for the labour.

It is noted that an excellent supply of water can be obtained from a well near the school. The Department agrees with you that as long as water can be obtained from the present source it is not necessary to dig a well on the school grounds.

Your obedient servant,

Miss Baird, Miss Comfort and Miss Howe, teachers on the Chippewa section of Caradoc Reserve, have requested that I take up with Dept. the building of car garages at each of their schools. In all three cases, their homes or boarding houses are miles from their school and it is necessary for them to use cars to get there and all day in all kinds of weather their cars must remain outside as there is no building to put them in. I understand a portable garage can be put up for around $100.00 and would ask your consideration of the erection of such a garage at each of the schools of the above-mentioned teachers.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

December 12th, 1929.

Memorandum.

Mr. Perrier,

I am of the opinion that garages should be provided at the Back Settlement and Muncey Day Schools. The use of a car, in both these cases, is a necessity and will continue to be so even in the event of a change of teachers.

In the case of Miss Baird at the Bear Creek School, I do not think a garage is necessary at all; her school is only a mile distant from the village of Middlemiss where she boards, and a car is not a necessity in getting to or from her school, in any condition of weather. I do not know of any garages being provided for teachers of the white schools in the municipality.

Inspector.
Ottawa, December 14, 1929.

Sir:

Referring to your monthly report of inspection of the Bear Creek, Muncey and Back Settlement Indian Day Schools in which you recommend that garages for the teachers' use be erected at each of these schools, I have to say that the Department will approve of the providing of garage accommodation at the Back Settlement and Muncey Day Schools. If weather conditions permit, you may arrange for the erection of a garage of the portable type at each of these schools. You should see that the site selected in each case does not interfere with the playground accommodation or the general appearance of the school building. We note you estimate the cost of the erection of a portable garage to be approximately $100, but, if possible, to do so, they should be furnished at each school at less cost. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the providing of suitable garage facilities for the teachers at both these schools. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Relative to the erection of a garage at the Bear Creek School, the Department does not consider that this is necessary at the present time. We understand that the teacher resides in the village of Middlemiss, which is only a mile distant from the school, and that a car is not necessary to get to and from her school in any condition of weather.

The Department will expect to hear from you as soon as the two garages authorized above have been completed, with full particulars as to the type, cost, etc.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

Sir:

I would beg to advise that on June 20th, I inspected the Back Settlement School, Caradoc Reserve and would recommend the following purchases and repairs for this school to be made during the coming summer holidays.

Sir:

I would beg to inform you that on my recent visit to Back Settlement Indian Day School I found the pump at this school in a dilapidated condition, the iron foot of the pump having been broken as well as some bolts being needed.

The platform on which the pump rests is half gone and is dangerous in its present condition and I would wish your authority to have this pump over-hauled at once. The school roof also leaks a little and although it was repaired during the past summer holidays it has not eliminated all the leaks.

The chimney is also crumbling and some bricks are dislodged and consideration should be given to a new roof being put on this school, and a new chimney built, and I believe that they will do this winter without much damage to the interior, and could be renewed next spring, when the weather will be more suitable.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Affs.,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, November 24, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the condition of the pump, roof and chimney at the Back Settlement Indian Day School.

Regarding the pump, I have to say that you should arrange as soon as possible to have the platform repaired and placed in a safe condition, and you may also have the pump overhauled and the necessary repairs carried out. You may also arrange to have any minor repairs required to the roof carried out, and the broken bricks in the chimney replaced and any pointing required made to the brick work. Our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and only the repairs absolutely necessary to make the building comfortable for the coming winter should be carried out at the present time. When this work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The question of installing a new roof and chimney on this building should be brought to the attention of the Department next spring, at which time you should give full particulars in detail of the work you would recommend be done and the approximate cost of same.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Sir,

I would wish to bring to your attention the need of a new roof on the Back Settlement Indian Day School of this agency and which I brought to your attention on Nov. 15th 1930.

I would recommend that a new shingle roof be installed during the present summer holidays at an estimated cost of $100.00. The eavetroughing of this school also needs repairing and in some places, conductor pipes need re-placing.

I would also recommend that a partition be erected in the wood shed at this school, so that the coal and wood, necessary for heating the school could be kept separate, as at the present time the coal is dumped on the ground in the wood shed and wood is thrown on top of it, and a partition in one end, separate for the coal, would eliminate any waste and also improve the appearance of this shed.

The whole cost of the repairs at the school should not exceed in the vicinity of $125.00 and this sum was placed in the estimates for this year, the roof being absolutely necessary, as it leaks and is causing damage to the plaster and interior of the classroom.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 8, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to reshingling the roof of the Back Settlement Indian Day School and giving an estimate of the cost, also stating that some repairs are required to the eaves troughing and conductor pipes.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have the roof of this school reshingled during the present summer holidays, and the repairs required to the eaves troughing and conductor pipes carried out. You may also arrange to have a partition erected in the woodshed, in order to keep the coal and wood separate. You should arrange for the purchase of the shingles and other materials required, and in making the purchase you should be guided by instructions which you have received. Indian labour should be employed as far as possible, proper time sheets, in duplicate, being kept. The total cost of the material and labour should not exceed your estimate of approximately $125.

After the work has been completed, please forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and time sheets, in duplicate, signed by the individual men employed and certified by yourself.

You should see that a satisfactory job is completed.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Form No. 518
Dear Sir:

I would report that the following repairs are needed at the Back Settlement Indian Day School and can be made during the coming Summer holiday period.

1. Paint exterior of school building proper two coats.
2. Replace 3 boards of siding before painting.
3. 1 pane of re-enforced glass for garage.
4. 1 coal fumacette for class room large size.
5. Repair and clean out outhouses.

To protect this building the exterior should be painted this year and the cost of two coats of paint would run in the vicinity of $50.00.

The cost of a large coal fumacette to replace the present coal stove would cost in the vicinity of $40.00 and is needed as the present stove is too small and badly worn out.

The total cost of materials and labour at this school would run in the close vicinity of $115.00.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Form No. 518
Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey.

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-2-5 of October 28th, with reference to purchase of supplies for schools of Caradoc Agency for noon day meals and before purchasing would wish your further instructions.

T.B. Escott & Co., London, Ont. wholesale grocers on the approved list can supply all lunch requirements and quotes the following prices:

Klim made from cream, 64¢ a pound.
Canned milk stock which is powdered skim milk and has been used in years past, 12¢ a pound.
Bulk cocoa, 10¢ a pound.
Tomato soup, 90¢ a dozen cans.
Vegetable soup, 90¢ a dozen cans.
Sugar, $5.55 per 100 pounds.

These prices are much better than can be obtained at local stores. Would the Department approve in some schools where fresh milk is obtainable to supply the same at 10¢ a quart, in preference to either milk stock or Klim, as some of the teachers complain there is no nourishment in milk stock whereas Klim is expensive at 64¢ a pound tin. If fresh milk were supplied for Cocoa, it would require from one to three quarts daily for each school, according to attendance and enrollment.

If soup were served one day a week over a period of 14 weeks commencing December 1st, it would take 3 dozen cans a week or a total of $35.00 for the full period. If served twice a week, it would double that amount.

Your definite instructions as to what expenditure to make would be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMORANDUM: Deputy Minister

The Department requires the following supplies for mid-day meal purposes at the five schools in the Caradoc agency:

- 205 lbs. sugar
- 125 lbs. Klim
- 32 lbs. cocoa

The Indian Agent was authorized to purchase the articles mentioned above and I enclose for your information a copy of his letter of November 4.

Last year, supplies for mid-day meal purposes were purchased from Lockwood Bros., Munsey, Ontario, and they charged as follows:

- Sugar - 7½¢ lb.
- Klim - 7½¢ lb.
- Cocoa - 11½¢ lb.

If the same price were paid locally this year as last year, there would be a considerable saving by purchasing wholesale, as mentioned in the Indian Agent's letter.

I would appreciate your advising me as soon as possible if Mr. Moore can be authorized to purchase from the wholesale or if you wish the purchases made locally.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I would advise you that a new ten foot gate is needed at the Back Settlement Indian Day School at a cost of $10.00, also costs for installation of gate, the present gate being in a very dilapidated condition.

In June 1936 and 1937 I did recommend the painting of the exterior of this building with two coats and the Department would not authorize the same and if only $400.00 is available for repairs of schools this year, this sum has already been exceeded on the River Settlement, Lower Muncey and Bear Creek Schools. If the painting is authorized, it would cost in the vicinity of $60.00, being $25.00 for materials and $35.00 for labour.

Your obedient servant,

- 30 granite mugs.

Muncey, Ontario,
May 5, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Further to my telegram of May 1, 1942, I have to report the complete destruction of the Rock Settlement School, situated on Lot No. 8, concession 2, No. 3 Side Road, with Miss. Howe, teacher.

After making inquiries as to causes of the fire I am convinced that the origin had some assistance but it is difficult to locate that origin. Miss. Howe, the teacher, assures me that there had been no fire in the stove since Monday, four days previous and then only a few pieces of paper were burned. She did not leave the School House until 4:30 p.m. that evening, and the Caretaker was there until 5 p.m. They both report there was no fire when they left, nor was there anything around that could cause fire without some assistance. It was five and a half hours after the Caretaker left that the fire was first noticed. However, the question now is one of accommodation.

The only building that I have seen or could recommend is the Anglican Church Basement. Of course, to use this, permission would have to be obtained from the Mission Board of the Anglican diocese.

We could perhaps gather up equipment from the other schools to start, however before taking any move I await your instructions.

Yours obedient servant,

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
May 8, 1942.

EX'D A

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the destruction by fire of the Back Settlement School.

In view of the suspicious circumstances surrounding this fire I presume that you have already requested the R.C.M.P. detachment to make a thorough investigation. If you have not done so, you should make these arrangements with them at once and any information they can obtain should be forwarded for our consideration.

It is so close to the end of the current academic year that there does not appear to be any use in endeavouring to secure another building. We will allow the teacher, Miss Howe, her salary to June 30. If arrangements cannot be made to secure quarters for the school for the coming academic year there is no doubt that we will be able to offer Miss Howe some other school. Consequently it would be appreciated if she would communicate with us before accepting any other school.

You might make inquiries with a view to ascertaining if we could secure the basement of the Anglican Church for school purposes for the academic year 1942-43. If so, you should let me know what rent the Anglican Church authorities require and give an estimate of the other expenses that would have to be incurred in order to prepare it as a classroom.

Yours truly,

Mr. Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
The Commissioner:

FORWARDED, 7-5-48. Owing to the isolated situation of the school and to the headway the fire had made before it was discovered, nothing could be learned of its possible origin.

1. On this date it was learned that the above school had been completely destroyed by fire during the late P.M. of the 30-4-42. Accompanied by Indian Agent G.W. Down, the writer patrolled to the above school, in an effort if possible to determine the cause of the fire.

2. Miss Helen Howe, teacher at the above school for the past 13 years was interviewed and informed the writer that everything appeared to be in good order with no sign of any fire when she left the school at approximately 4:30 p.m. of the 30-4-42, and further that she had had no fire in the stove since Monday April 25th, when she had burned some waste paper. Miss Howe could throw no light on the cause of this fire.

3. Mr. James Henry, caretaker was next interviewed, and stated that he had swept the school out after the teacher had left on the 30-4-42, and had left the school at approximately 5:00 p.m. when everything appeared to be in good order. All doors in the school were locked by Mr. Henry when he left, as well as the windows, and he could not throw any light on the cause of this fire.

4. It was learned that Mrs Fred Kocheigo, daughter of the caretaker, was the first person to arrive at the scene of the fire at approximately 10:00 p.m., with the hopes to the front door which she opened and noticed that the choir interior of the school was a mass of flames, which shot out the door when it was opened. Mrs Kocheigo informed the writer that the fire appeared to be burning the most in the vicinity of the teachers desk, and at that time the fire had gained such headway that it was impossible to save the frame constructed building.

5. Mrs Kocheigo further informed the writer that the doors and windows appeared to be in good order on her arrival, and immediately that she opened the front door the glass in the windows started to break from the draft caused by the opening of the door and the intense heat. No one was seen in the vicinity of the school which is situated in a very isolated part of the Reserve, which no doubt accounts for the fact that the fire was not noticed until it had gained such headway.

6. The building destroyed in this fire was approximately 35 years old, of frame construction with a cement base, one floor, no basement and measured approximately 35 feet by 27 feet. There is no fire fighting equipment of any kind at or near the school, with the exception of a few water pails. Owing to the fact that the school was totally destroyed, it is impossible to determine the origin or cause of the fire. There is no electric lights in the school, thus eliminating any possibility of a short circuit. The fact that the fire appeared to be burning the most near the teachers desk indicates that it may have started at that point.

N.S.I.

CONCLUDED.

R.A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. of Welfare & Training, Ottawa.

Re Back Settlement School.

In connection with the above mentioned school, there are a few necessary expenditures involved in which I would prefer to have your authority.

(1) It will be necessary to purchase fuel. In this, I have no way of estimating the required tonnage, as the Church authorities usually burn wood. However, wood fuel is out of the question. It cannot be purchased. I think five tons of anthracite coal should be sufficient, as the fires will not be started until after Christmas. The price per ton of anthracite delivered would be $16.50.

(2) The question of out-houses. In this connection, we have two comparatively new buildings standing on the old school site which could be moved and I propose moving them to the Church grounds. The cost of moving would be approximately $15.00.

(3) It is requested that we cover the back stairway, which is the one to be used, with some type of matting. For this purpose, I suggest Coco Matting. This, I think can be purchased through the T.Eaton Co., of Toronto and I would suggest it be ordered direct from Ottawa. Amount required, 8 yards, 2 or 3 feet wide. Cost not known.

(4) A complaint has been received from Wilfred Riley, whose farm adjoins the Church property and he is anxious that his barns and stacks should be protected by erecting a fence about sixteen feet parallel to his own fence. This of course is only a request and cannot be enforced. However, his barns and stacks are very close and as a precautionary measure, I am prepared to recommend his request.

Muncey, Ontario
Sept. 15th, 1944.

I wish to draw your attention to the continued, unsatisfactory conditions at the Back Settlement Indian Day School. Teaching, as you are aware, has been conducted, since the destruction, by fire, of the regular school building in May, 1942, in the basement of the Anglican Church.

I think you will agree that, while the basement of a Church has its place for social gatherings and perhaps Church meetings, it is hardly the place for little children to spend hours in pursuit of an education. Such has been the case for the children of this section during the last 2½ years. Cement floors, dampness, and most inadequate lighting, to say nothing of teacher inconveniences, are all factors against a continuance of the use of this type of educational classroom. Then again, school closes every Friday P.M. until Monday A.M. during which time school equipment, children's text books, etc., are not only an annoyance to Church organizations but are sometimes piled in untidy heaps in an endeavour to get them out of the way and any damage, of course, is always attributed to school children and the responsibility of the Department of Indian Affairs.

When the Department acquired the right, through the good graces of the Most Reverend, the Archbishop of the Diocese of Huron, to use their building, it was not considered a permanent concession; and I think you will agree that we have overstepped the concession and perhaps imposed upon the co-operative spirit of the Anglican Church officials, although to-date they have made no direct overture as to moving out. But the congregation have, on several occasions, intimated that the concession was only a temporary one and granted on the promise of a new school being erected in the very near future. They also point out that their social gatherings are curtailed and hampered on account of desks and school equipment stored in the church in the latter cannot be questioned, and I have repeatedly advised that a new school is contemplated which usually provokes some caustic remarks about promises emanating from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. However, in all fairness to Church officials, congregation, teacher and pupils, to say nothing of the Department's responsibility, the matter of providing and building a modern school should be given serious consideration.
While I am on the question of schools which are, of course, institutions of education; and our method along this particular line has, in recent press articles and letters, been severely criticized, may I also point out that two years ago the Muncey School was closed, the reason being insufficient number of pupils enrolled. This was perhaps justified but, owing to the location of other schools at lesser distance and places on children belonging to the particular area. There was also a condition in connection with this building in that it did not belong to the Department, and, I am informed the Muncey Band granted the use of this, their Council Hall, until other arrangements were made. These concessions are still remembered with bitterness and as unbroken promises. However, I am not interested in past administration, conditions or concessions, but I am, particularly, interested in the education of our Indian people, and the present lay-out and type of makeshift, ill-lighted, unventilated classrooms, that exist on the Chipewyan and Muncey Reserves, is not conducive to this end. There is, in fact, an urgent need for the erection of two centrally located modern schools on the Chipewyan and Muncey Reserves. Personally I am in favour of consolidated schools, with continuation classrooms, where our Indian children may be classified and their education guided into channels according to I.Q. However, the type of school with its attendant educational values is a matter for Departmental policy. But I would emphasize the urgent need of immediate consideration in connection with the Anglican Church basement.

Ottawa, September 20, 1944.

Mr. G. W. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ontario.

Re: Back Settlement Day School.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 18th instant, in which you intimate that conditions at the temporary classroom conducted in the basement of the Anglican Church are far from satisfactory.

You are no doubt aware that the Government has not built Indian day or residential schools anywhere in the Dominion during the war period, despite the fact that a number of schools have been destroyed by fire during this period. We have, for example, the classroom building at Alberni, destroyed by fire three years ago, and where instruction is now provided in the wash-rooms. A similar condition exists at File Hills, Saskatchewan. Then, again, the large day school at the Caughnawaga Reserve, near Montreal, a 12-room building, was destroyed and has not been rebuilt. I am not arguing at the moment that two wrongs constitute a right, but I do feel, although it may be difficult to convince the Indians that such is the case, that the people at your agency have been particularly fortunate so far as school accommodation is concerned.

It is just possible that the policy pursued by the Government has been wrong, but whether it is wrong or right, it is based on the fact that taxation, for the time being, is as heavy as the Canadian people can bear and that the material and manpower that would be ordinarily used in the construction of schools was necessary in our war effort. Indeed, there were a great many who believed that unless we could survive nothing else mattered.

It so happens that I have before me a letter from the Principal of the Mount Elgin Institute,
in which he intimates that despite his best efforts to provide worthwhile vocational courses at the school, his enrolment at this date is less than 50% of the enrolment authorized by the Department. If conditions are unsatisfactory in the basement of the Anglican Church, would it be possible to have the pupils in attendance transferred to the Institute? It does not seem fair to me that the taxpayers should be called upon to pay the cost of a building program on a reserve while less than half of the available accommodation at the residential school is unoccupied.

I am anxious that you should discuss conditions at the Anglican Church with the Indian parents concerned, with the Principal of the Residential School and with the teacher of the day school. In fact, it might be possible to enter into an agreement whereby transportation for these children to the residential school might be provided, if the parents are opposed to the regular enrolment of their children at the school.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

8th February, 1946.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ontario.

My dear Sir:

I have been approached officially by one of our congregations of Indians in the Caradoc Agency expressing an urgent hope that our Church basement, which has been rented for a School to your Department since I think the Autumn of 1942, can be restored to their use.

The basement of the Church is used for the various organizations of the congregation and their work seems to be curtailed in consequence of its being used as a School.

I have no doubt that this matter has been in the minds of your officials, and also the fact that an underground basement is not the best place for School purposes. Perhaps your Department is planning to do something at an early date.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

CH/CJ
Archbishop of Huron.
Ottawa, February 16, 1946.

Dear Archbishop Seager:

I have your letter of the 8th instant with reference to our use of the basement of the Anglican Church on the Caradoc Reserve for school purposes.

I realize that our use of this building is inconveniencing the congregation. However, I trust that you will find it possible to allow us to continue using this basement at least another year. Owing to conditions beyond our control, I cannot see any possibility of providing a new building at this particular point this year.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Most Rev. C. A. Seager, D.D.,
Archbishop of Huron,
Bishop Gronyn Hall,
London, Ont.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Schools and Education:

As time goes on the average Indian Day School presents a problem and I am convinced that a change in the management and general set up of Indian education is upon us. Accessibility, teacher accommodation, over crowding, insecurity and low salaries are contributing factors in what might be termed "The March of Education." If consolidated schools is not the answer, serious thought must be given to a building program of adequate class-room accommodation and opportunities for higher education.

The march of time is away from the one class-room little red school house and the time is here for our Indians to demand the same rights and facilities as their white brothers. If we are to help our Indian people and prepare them for the years that lie ahead, serious thought must be given to education and proper school facilities.

The Back Settlement Indian School, as you are aware, has, for the past three and one-half years been conducted in the basement of the Anglican Church. This was never a popular arrangement, especially with the church's congregation and I understand that the local management recently petitioned Church Officials to have the government assume its own responsibility.

From my regular school visits I found school management, under varying circumstances, favourable. Academically, I think our Indian children compare favourably with other sections. The percentage of passes at summer Entrance examinations was very satisfactory and several pupils are continuing their education in Continuation Schools and Collegiates under white supervision.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Muncey, Ontario,
Dec. 19, 1947.

While visiting the various schools I noticed, which I have on many occasions, a pail of water, uncovered, with a dipper and little children taking the dipper from one another dipping it into the pail and drinking. This, to my mind, is a very unsatisfactory condition and I am suggesting that an effort be made to correct the condition by purchasing filters. I think there is a type of filter being used in many of our white rural schools which is very satisfactory; and the price is somewhere about $7.00 or $8.00 each. We would need at least seven—a total cost of approximately $60.00 or $65.00.

If you approve, and will advise, I will make enquiries as to where purchases may be made.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
SUPERINTENDENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

January 3, 1948.

Mr. Geo. W. Down, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Muncey, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 19th ultimo, file 130-1, we regret that owing to lack of funds, it is not possible to authorize the expenditure that would be required to place water filters in the schools in your agency.

There is a cheaper type of water cooler that should prove suitable and you might make further inquiries with a view to ascertaining if you can obtain water coolers at a more reasonable cost. You can then communicate with us after the first of April when funds from the new appropriation will be available.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD
Ottawa, March 15, 1948.

Memorandum:

MAJOR G.A.F. CLARK

Mount Elgin Indian Day School

This will confirm our conversation with regard to the above Day School. It would seem that relationships between the Principal and his staff are not what we would require and that it will be necessary for you to report upon conditions there in some detail. Apparently Mr. Johnston is not a good disciplinarian and, as a result, there is much freedom between the pupils and this particular teacher. Complaints have been made with regard to his association with the older girls. There is also evidence of too much freedom between the older boys and Mr. Johnston during recess and lunch hours. You can investigate these "stories" during your visit there and I wish to be advised as to whether we should contemplate the future employment of this teacher.

I would also like to know just how much teaching Mr. Joblin is doing. We are now paying four teachers at this school and I would like to know exactly what the teaching load of each teacher is. You might also check as to the number of visits which Mr. Joblin has made to the day schools of the agency.

Back Settlement

The third point which I wish reported on is with respect to the contemplated construction of a one-room school at Back Settlement. I would like a specific report from you as to where this new school can best be located. You can also investigate the question of land required for such a building. It will be our standard one-room school plan and I would suggest that you mail ahead a set of the plans, specifications and bill of materials for this project. I would like to have this school
constructed on a day labour basis, using the present foreman at the Mount Elgin Day School as the foreman for the one-room school. However, you can check into this matter with Colonel Randle when you are at Caradoc. It would be necessary to allow at least two months for requisitions to pass through the Departmental Purchasing Agent's hands and to arrive on the spot at Back Settlement. We would endeavour to rush the cement so that the excavation could be proceeded with.

Bernard E. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Your File 7-2-5 (WTL)

Further to correspondence in connection with water coolers in the several schools of the Caradoc Agency and, in particular, your letter of January 3rd.

It is noted that you request an application for such equipment immediately following the close of the 1947-48 fiscal year, but I am not quite sure what the attached notation to your letter means, copy of which is attached. Does this mean that you have ordered the coolers or that they may be obtained through the George M. Henry Company? If so, I see very little difference in the price I quoted and the price they quote. However, perhaps you have catalogues dealing fully with school equipment and could choose a type of cooler suitable for our purposes. I think most of our teachers would be satisfied with any type of cooler that would do away with the open pail into which every child dips his cup.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,

It is rather late now but to be in time and to make sure of the 1948-49 allotment I would request that I be advised of the amounts available. Allotments in 1946-47 were as follows:

April 24, 1943.

Mr. George W. Down, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Muncey, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, it is regretted that no allowance was made for mid day meal purposes at the schools in your Agency during the past winter.

We will be prepared to allow an amount for this purpose for the academic year 1943-49 and I suggest that you write again about the first of September. At that time you should recommend the amount you think should be allowed for the new class room at Oneida No. 2 and also the new school under Mr. Joblin. When this letter is received, we will also make a decision regarding the amount to be allowed for manual training during the 1948-49 academic year.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Back Settlement Indian Day School.

This is to advise you that it is our intention to erect a new Indian day school at the above point and to vacate the basement of the Anglican Church, presently used for school purposes.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Back Settlement Indian Day School.

A sum for the construction of an Indian Day School at Back Settlement, Caradoc Indian Reserve, Muncey, Ontario is included in our Main Estimates for 1948-49. At the present time, we are using the basement of an Anglican Church for school purposes. We have had a letter from the Anglican Bishop intimating that they will be requiring this basement for other purposes during the next year.

It is our intention, therefore, to erect a standard one room school with attached teacherage during the forthcoming summer. Mr. F.E. Mahler of Mount Brydges, Ontario, is building a four room school for us at Mount Elgin on the same Reserve. This school is now nearing completion and we feel that Mr. Mahler has done a satisfactory job. He is willing to undertake the supervision of the construction of the one room school required at Back Settlement at the rate of $1.50 per hour. If this offer is accepted, the Department would provide the materials and we will use Indian labour almost entirely.

It is recommended that approval be given to the hiring of Mr. Mahler at the rate of $1.50 per hour to supervise the construction of this one room school.

BFN/RM.

Director.

Dear Sir:

Re School at Batchewana.

Some of the people living at Batchewana are very anxious for a school; and as I have learned from Mr. McNabb the Indian Agent here, the Department of Indian Affairs is about to establish a school at that point. I thought it well to write you to see if some concerted action could be taken whereby all the settlers and Indians could be served by the one school.

In order for the Ontario Department of Education to establish a school under the Public School Act a section would be formed, trustees elected and they would then have power to rent or build a house.

I understand the Indians are all Catholics; there are four or five Protestant families and these are very anxious that the school be a public school if possible. Will the school that the Indian Department will establish be a Catholic or Protestant one?

I trust that we shall be able to agree upon some basis that will serve the whole community without duplicating the expense or equipment.

Let us hear what the Department will do in the case.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, October 21, 1912.

Mr. Pedley,

Miss Eva Pilon, who was given charge of the new school at Batchewana Bay, writes the Department that she opened the school on the 2nd instant and had, at the time she wrote her letter, the 12th instant, 22 pupils attending the school and more to come in. She says the pupils are intelligent and she feels certain that they will make good progress, but she is disappointed with the conditions. The only available boarding house within any reasonable distance is with a half-breed family, one mile from the school. She says that she has been put to considerable expense, both in her clothes and railway fares, and she finds that $350.00, the salary allowed her, will not be sufficient to meet her expenses and she trusts that the Department will give her an increase.

When Miss Pilon was appointed the Department informed her that she would be able to get board with a white family. This statement was based on Mr. Shore's
memorandum, in which the opening of a school at Batchewana Bay was recommended. There is no doubt about Batchewana Bay being an isolated place in the winter and I can easily understand that a young girl would be disheartened at the prospect of having to spend a winter there at a salary of $350.00 a year.

As there is no doubt that she will leave by Christmas unless she gets a higher salary, I think the Department would be quite justified, in the interests of the Indian children there, in offering her a substantial increase in order to retain her services, as there is no prospect of getting another teacher in there till next September if she resigns.

I think the salary should be increased to $450.00 per year in a reasonable salary for Mi'kmaq teachers.

Funds available

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent McNabb forwards an application from Miss M. Mercier, teacher of the Batchewana School, for an increase of $50.00 in her salary. She is now paid at the rate of $400.00 per annum.

When I was at Batchewana last November with Mr. Agent McNabb I saw Miss Mercier and the school. There were 15 children present out of an enrolment of 31, all the children of school age there. I had not time to see the children in their classes, as we got there about noon and left about two o'clock immediately after the payments were made. I was favourably impressed with Miss Mercier, who is a strong active young woman, and she seemed quite contented with her surroundings, as she lives with her uncle, who has a trading post. There are only three white families there and the last teacher was forced to resign owing to the fact that she could not get a suitable boarding place and was unable to agree with Mrs. Miller. Miss Mercier is quite able to hold her own and it would be
a difficult matter to replace her, as Batchewana is a most isolated situation and few white teachers would care to stay there for any time. She is popular with the Indians and it would be a pity to lose her.

The Department purchased a lot at Batchewana and proposed to put up a new school building with teacher's quarters attached. As long as Miss Mercier remains there would be no need to go to this expense, as the old schoolhouse is quite good enough for the purpose and quite comfortable and, as she is living with her relatives, she would not make use of the teacher's quarters.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant No 408014-1 in reference to living accommodation for the Teacher at Batchewana, and in reply would say that the accommodation is not very good, the school is isolated in the winter as there are no persons living near there, and a Teacher to get into a good place to Board would have to walk from Mr O'Donnell a distance of at least two miles, she might be able to get in with an Indian family but as a general thing they are not the place where a young lady would like to stop.

I do not know of any house that could be rented near the school and supposing there was a house it would be so far from any other neighbors that it would not be a fit place.

If I might give you my view of the matter I would say not to send a Teacher up there till Spring and if the new School was not built next year just keep it open from May 1st to November 1st.

In the summer season the Dominion Fish Co keep a store and the Teacher might be able to get Board with his family, just at present I cannot recommend any other course.

Awaiting your further instructions,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Sir -

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Batchawana Indian Day School states that he was surprised at the situation at this point. He, however, did not know whether this building could be obtained from the owner for school purposes.

He also states that there were only 3 children on the roll, while, at least, 9 should have been present.
