It might be possible to rent this house from the owner, and have it fitted up as a classroom and teacher's living quarters. It seems a waste of money to continue the school situated as it is - too far away for the Indian children to attend. The Inspector strongly recommends that arrangements be made to have the school located near Batchawana Village in order that all the children of school age can attend.

If this resolution is obtained, arrangements could then be made to have the building erected early next spring. You should point out to the Indians that, under the present arrangements, the success achieved hardly warrants the Department in keeping the school open, as, owing to the distance which the church building is situated from the majority of the Indians, it is impossible for the children to attend. "ATTENTION OF THE DEPUTY MINISTER"

I have been requested by several of the Indian Residents of Batchawana to write you requesting a change of Teacher.

If necessary the Indian Residents here will forward a petition to your Department asking for a change of Teacher, to start September Term. Ottawa, August 19, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of August 6th, in which you intimate that you are communicating with the Department in response to a request that has reached you from a number of Indian residents at Batchewana, who are anxious to secure a change of teacher at the Batchewana Bay Indian Day School.

I may state that, immediately following the receipt of your letter, a careful study was made of the Inspectors' reports covering the work of this teacher over a period of ten years. These reports appear to be uniformly satisfactory and creditable to the teacher. I note that the reports are signed by three Inspectors, working under the direction of the Department of Education of the province of Ontario.

Inspector Greening, in a report dated June 15th, 1937, states:-

"Cleanliness of pupils - Good.
Obedience - Excellent.
Conduct of pupils in school - Excellent."

In his report on examination of the classes, the Inspector states:-

"The classes were examined in Reading and Oral Language, in Spelling and Arithmetic. The older pupils were also asked to do some work in Written English. The results were quite good, distinct progress being evident

A. L. M. Allan, Esq.,
Batchewana Bay,
Ont.
evident in the written work."

It would appear that the Inspector, when he last visited this school, was accompanied by a missionary. In the last paragraph of his report he states:

"I believe that it is a good thing to bring to the attention of the public the work being done by the Indian Department in these schools, and so, at our visit to this school, we were accompanied by a Baptist missionary (Rev. Mr. Readhouse) of Toronto, who had travelled around the world a good deal and who at the present time is resting at the Sault. I feel sure that Mr. Readhouse realized the good work that was being done at this particular school and I was more than pleased when I was able to show him written work done by the four pupils of Grades 7 and 8, which was of a very high order for such a school."

In addition to these reports received from the Inspectors, the Indian Agent for the district has, on more than one occasion, referred to this school and to the satisfactory progress of the pupils in attendance.

In view of these reports, you can readily understand the reluctance of the Department to consider a change of teacher at this school. It would be exceedingly difficult for this Department to obtain the services of fully qualified teachers, unless such teachers were given a reasonable assurance of security of tenure and that they would not be dismissed from their positions as long as their work was conscientiously performed and satisfactory to the Department. I am convinced, after a careful study of the Inspectors' reports, that there are few public school teachers in the Dominion with a more creditable record than the record established by Miss Robicheau at the Batchewana School.

It is just possible that, in the interests of this teacher, herself, we may have to consider the advisability of changing her to a school where her work will be more fully appreciated. Such changes, however, are not easily
easily effected and should not be considered unless there is a school available to which this teacher could be transferred at a salary equal to, or greater than, the salary she is now receiving. The officials inform me that they know of no such school to which she could be transferred at the present time.

May I thank you for bringing this matter to my personal attention and express the hope that the information I am submitting for your consideration will prove satisfactory to you and to the residents who may be interested in the progress of the Indian pupils at Batchewana Bay.

Yours very truly,

Extract from Inspector Greening's report on the Rabbit Island Indian Day School visited on May 17, 1944.

While I was at Sagamook the other day I was distressed to learn from Mr. Agent Lawrence, (with whom my relations are also most cordial), that the Indians at Batchawana were petitioning for a change of teacher.

This matter is a hardy perennial, and keeps coming to the surface. A deputation once waited upon me in the time of Mr. Agent Sims, with a similar request. I consulted the agent and said that I would be glad to listen to anybody concerned at the school that afternoon. The Indians admitted quite frankly that they had nothing whatever against Miss Robicheau, except that she had been at Batchawana too long and that they would like a new teacher. When I explained to them that it would be difficult, perhaps, to find her another school they replied that they regretted that very much as she was a fine woman but they would like a new teacher.

A reference to my reports upon the Batchawana School will show my own opinion of Miss Robicheau. Any young lady who could live in a place like Batchawana for almost twenty years without having given anyone any chance for a little "choice gossip" must certainly be a genuinely sterling character.

If the Indian Affairs Branch feels that a change might be desirable at Batchawana, (and, considering the length of time Miss Robicheau has been there, the Indians are perhaps not too unreasonable), I hope that something good can be found for her. Perhaps she would like the Rabbit Island School.

Dear Father Dwyer:

I am sorry I did not reply to your letter sooner, but I just found it on my desk the other day and have reviewed our file with reference to the Batchawana School.

In a recent report the Indian Agent stated there were only five Treaty Indian children attending this school last year and that the 11 other children who attended were half-breeds or enfranchised Indians. Sir,

There are a number of Children that are living in what is called Frenchtown at the western side of the Reserve that cannot attend the School in the winter on account of the distance, and if they are to be educated they must be sent to some boarding school. I would suggest a remedy for this, if the Batchewana Band were allowed to purchase the Residence of the late Chief Pat Sayers it could be fitted up for a School room and also used as a Hall, and as two Teachers are kept at the Catholic School one of them could be removed over to Frenchtown as they are all Catholics living there. The place could be fitted up so that the teacher could have living quarters upstairs and the first floor used for School and Hall, this arrangement would do away with the necessity of sending any children to the Spanish, I would be pleased to have your opinion on the above suggestion.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of March 8th No 13-6-1. in reference to School at French Bay at Garden River and in reply would say, that I was waiting until I knew whether we could buy the Pat Sayer House, before giving an estimate of the cost of a building.

OTTAWA, Sept. 22nd, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, requesting authority to purchase the house belonging to the Pat Sayer Estate and have it fitted up for school purposes for the benefit of the Indian children residing on the western side of the Batchewana Reserve, and furnishing an estimate of the cost.

In reply, I beg to say that, upon full consideration of the matter, the Department is of the opinion that the results that would be achieved would not warrant the expenditure required to purchase the building, fit it up and in the expense of carrying on the school. As you have been informed, the Department is unable to provide funds for the purpose, and it would unduly tax the funds of the band to provide the money at the present time.

It is thought that satisfactory arrangements could be made with a reliable man who has horses and a good wagon to draw the Indian children who reside on the western side of the Reserve to and from their homes to the Garden River (R.C.) Indian Day School, where there is ample accommodation for them.

I will, therefore, be pleased if you will consider this suggestion. You should state whether the services of a competent man could be obtained who would enter into an agreement to provide the equipment and draw the children to and from school each day. You should also state the amount that would be charged each day for the purpose. It would be necessary for him to take the children in time in the morning and bring them home in the afternoon.

I may say that this arrangement has been tried on other Reserves, and when the services of a reliable man have been obtained, to draw the children to and from school daily, has met with fair success. It will, no doubt, be possible to arrange with an Indian who has a team and a wagon; or the services of a white man could be obtained to do the work.

It is considered that this arrangement could be carried out at a moderate cost, and the children and teacher receive better accommodation in the Roman Catholic Day School where there is every facility for the children's education, and also accommodation for the teacher.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Agents should see that full explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks," if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.

9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.
